div.p: THE Woman turn'd Bully. A COMEDY. Acted at the Duke's Theatre.
LONDON: Printed by I. C. for T. Dring, at the Harrow at the corner of Chancery-lane in Fleet-street. 1675.

list.head: The Persons represented.
list.item: TRUMAN, A young Gentleman of the Temple, possest of an Estate, and lives handsomely.
GOODFEILD, His Friend, newly come to Town.
DOCKET, An antient Attorney, a very Law-driver.
TRUPENNY, Madam Goodfeilds Country-Steward, an old formal Coxcomb.
DASHWEL, Docket's Clerk, like his Master.
SPRUCE, Another Clerk to Docket, a lively fellow.
Madam GOODFEILD, A rich Country-Widow, who drinks and takes Tobacco, and can't speak a word out of the Country-Element: she hates the Town; but comes up about an immergent Law-affair.
BFTTY GOODFEILD, An aiery young Lady her Daughter, come up to London after her Mother, in mans Apparel. She personates a Town-Gallant, and discourses out of Plays.
FRANK, Her Maid, in the like Disguize.
LOVEAL, The Widows woman, a stale Maid, who longs for a Husband: very fond.
LUCIA, A young Lady, Niece and Ward to Docket,

div.head: PROLOGUE.
div.l: So ill success have Poets now adaies,
That shortly none will dare to write you Plays.
Dramatick Wit is ominous of late;
The little Flash does still prognosticate
A Paper-war, or a more scurvie Fate.
And (like a graceless Child) Heroick Rattle
Is realliz'd, and turn'd the Poets Battle.
T'avoid such fears, we shall present to day
An innocent and unprovoking Play:
And that's his comfort, th'Author bid me say.
'Tis plain, well meant; hardly a Song or Dance,
Scene, nor Machine, its Credit to advance.
Yo've nothing here of such prodigious strains,
To swell your Envie greater than his Pains.
But being of English growth, we've cause to fear,
'Gainst home-bred Wit their censure too severe,
Who still usurp a Power to disapprove
What the sick Fancie can't digest, or Love.
Persist— But Letchers thus, when they decline,
Borrow both Heat and Love from sparkling Wine.
And though poor Chloris thinks their Love's her Prize,
'Tis Burgundy becomes her Sacrifice.
While healthful Lovers vigorously improve
With Native Food and heat th'Entrigues of Love.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: HOnest Ned Goodfeild, i'faith I'm as glad to see thee as any man living. Once more thou art welcome to London. But, what good Star directed thee to my Chamber?

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Marry, that did the good Porter: he shewed me the Stair-case; and when I mounted, the first I happened to meet was your Boy. Gad, Iack, thou livest here a delicate life; these are better Lodgings than thou hadst at the Colledge.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Aye, faith, and somewhat better Company. But what a Devil makes thee tarry thus long at Cambridge? Sure thou art graduated up to the Ears by this time. Dost thou intend for the Pulpit, or by the way of Physick, wilt thou cure thy friends of all Diseases?—

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: No more of that, good Iack; I have a Mother alive, who till I come to age (of which I lack not many weeks) is also my Guardian. She is a good Soul (as Sancho said of his Wife) but of a downright Country-principle. She hates your City here, and all that belongs to't. Looke ye, Iack; when you left the Colledge, I would have follow'd you with all my heart, but my Mother very gravely, and like a Mother, writ me her Commands, and I think, sent one of her servants to acquaint me, that I must still continue my Studies where I was: for to come into the Country, and enter into Commission of the Peace, I was yet too young; and to go to the Inns a Court she would never think on't, for that was the ready way to be undone, London being the very sink of all Debauchery.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p:
Hold there: Let me view thee well. Dost thou come from
the University, and charge us with Debauchery? O tempora! O mores! Belike then you made this Voyage without your Mothers knowledge?

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Aye.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Why there's a dutiful Son. Art not thou asham'd, Ned?

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: For what? for coming to Town without her leave?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: No, Ned, for blaming the poor Town, for a lewd ill-manner'd Town, or as your Mother thinks it, a sink of Perdition. I tell thee, Ned, thou art quite beside the Cushion. Minde what I say: Your University-men no sooner come hither, but they forget their dear Art of Drinking. And for a Clap, or so, many are so far from getting it here, that they bring it with em.— Boy, see who knocks.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Sir, here's Mr. Docket's Clerk has a Message from his Master, he says, and desires you would please to dispatch him.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Dispatch him? why how long has he waited?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Not at all, Sir; but you know he's so full of his Law-terms, he can't speak without 'em.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Bid him enter.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: (at the door) Mr. Dashwel, you may enter.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Sir, I humbly thank ye. May it please you, Mr. Truman, my Master desires to speak with you some time this afternoon.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: How does he do?

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Very well, and in good practice, I thank God, Sir.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: I'm glad on't. Tell your Master, Sir, I will not fail to wait on him about three a clock.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: By no means, Sir, for then he'll be very busie in examining a special Plea in Trover, which will hold him at least half an hour.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Why then I'll be with him at five.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: That can't be, Sir, for then he'll be gone out to the Walks to meet his Brother Nuper, and signe Judgment betwixt Wiseman and Spendal: 'Tis a 2000 l. Action, and cannot be put off.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: No? What a Devil— why then tell him I'll not fail to come as soon as I've dined, 'twixt one and two a clock.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Aye, Sir, I think that will do very well. Fare you well, Sir.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Godb'w'ye Mr. Dashwel.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Oh Lord! Sir, I had almost forgot; you must not come then, for then there will be with him a certain Country-Lady, one Madam Goodfeild, who comes about business; and you must not come then by any means.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Madam Goodfeild, say you friend?

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, of Darbyshire.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: D'you know her business?

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: To that, Sir, I answer Ignoramus: I can say little—

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: To the purpose, I'm sure.—

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Her Servant, one Mr. Trupenny, was with my Master this morning, to desire an Imparlance after Dinner, and then she'll open her Case.—

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Mr. Dashwel, when shall I come to your Master? be brief.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: E'en when you please, Sir.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Well then, I'll come a little before three, e're he goes upon his Plea; and that will be a good time.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Aye, Sir, a very good time: Your Servant Sir, your Servant Gentlemen.
sp.stage: Turning Dashwel to the door, and thrusting him forwards.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: My Mother in Town! this amazes me.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Suspend thy wonder a little, Ned; I'll know all if possible, when I go to Dockets.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: In the mean time, what a Devil is this Docket, and this formal Coxcomb his man, that comes with such a damn'd Message?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: 'Tis worth your enquiry indeed, for they are two as notable Creatures as e're were shew'd at Bartholomew-Fair. The man you've seen already, and should you see him a year together, you would see neither more nor less in him; yet people of his Tribe say he's a good Clerk (as they phrase it.) He's one that manages his Masters Practice so assiduously, that he can do nothing else— But a pox on him, what do I spend so many words of such an Owl?

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Then for the Master.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p:
Aye, the Master. There's a rare plece of flesh for ye— never was Master and Man so proportion'd to one another. You have heard part of the man's Character already; and, If the man such dulness have— you know the old Rime in the Arcadia. To
be brief, (for I hate to discourse of such unpleasant subjects) He is a pure downright Attorney, with as little mixture of Gentleman or Scholar as possible can be imagined to one who lives in London, the Staple of refin'd converse. To this I must add, he is Old and Rich.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: I'the name of Wonder, how came you acquainted with such things as these? Is this the refin'd Converse, you talk of?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Oh, Ned! thereby hangs a tale. You must know then, in an evil hour, I owe him 6000 l. which my Father heretofore borrow'd, partly to marry a Daughter, and partly on other occasions: For this Debt he mortgaged five hundred a year, which Mortgage has been now forfeited about four year, and he in the Devils name, has enter'd. Since my Father's death, Ned, I have been very sensible of this loss, it being (betwixt you and I) the best half of my Estate. In fine, I have been several times with him to take in this Mortgage, and get him to release the Estate. I have offer'd him, to that end, to pay down 3000 l. with the Interest due, and a Judgment from my self and two substantial Citizens, for the other three.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: And so he replies that you offer him to his loss, and that he has eleven Points of the Law against ye; does he not?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Much to that purpose; but in his Gibberish, he tells me, Nul tort nul disseisin, I must not complain of wrong, he has but what the Law gives him, and Executio Iuris non habet Injuriam: And this is all I could ever get from him, till yesterday, and then we were in somewhat more complaisant terms. He sends for me now, I am confident, about this business.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Well, is this all you can tell me of him?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Proceed.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: He has a pretty Niece, that I must bring you acquainted with.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Me! Gad Iack, you have made such a fine Character of him, I have no ambition to know any of the Breed.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: You mistake me, Ned Goodfeild; she is no ways a kin to the dis-ingenuity of her Uncle. Believe me, Friend, she is both Young, Pretty, of a good Humour, and besides a Fortune.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: And with all these good Qualities, why do not you strike her up, and by that means pay off your Mortgage?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Not so fast: The Affair is less feazable to me than any man, for several reasons that I know. Her Father dying, left this his onely Daughter, and 6000 l. to the management of his Wives Brother, this Docket, who he appointed her Guardian, with this Proviso in his Will, that if she married without her said Guardian's consent, then to forfeit the said sum intended for her Portion, and that her Uncle might dispose of it as he thought fit. Her Uncle, a covetous Jew, has swallow'd all this Estate already in imagination, intending never to marry her with his consent: To that end, confines her (while with him in London) constantly to her Chamber, never suffering her to see the open air, unless once or twice a fortnight in the Temple or Lincolns-Inn-Gardens; and that too, with himself or some such trusty Governour.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: These are Impediments, I confess Iack, especially to a Debter.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: This is not all. The damn'd dull course of life her Uncle has imposed upon her, has rendred both her discourse and behaviour very reserved, or to say true, a little heavy; which suits not at all with my fancie; for I must have my Mistriss, Ned, full of Air and Gayety to the utmost extent.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Faith, then I've a Sister will fit thee to a hair.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Where is she, Ned?

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Ah Pox, she's in Darby-shire.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: That's a great way off. But how d'you know she's not come up with your Mother?

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Oh, it can never enter into my thoughts: She'll sooner send her to the Nunnery at Ghent, than bring her hither. She believes this Town spoils all young men that come to it; but for women, she's confident the very air of London meets 'em, and debauches 'em at Highate. Hang me if I can comprehend what a Devil brings my Mother her self up: it must be some extraordinary occasion. She has not made such a Voyage, to my knowledge, this twenty years.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Well, we shall know all when I have been at Dockets. In the mean time, Ned, thou shalt dine with me: I'll acquaint thee with the humour of the Eating-houses. Boy, give me my Sword, and follow me.

div.head: SCENE II.
The Street.
div.stage: Enter Betty Goodfeild, and Franck her Maid, both in mans Apparel.

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: NOw, Franck, that we are arrived at London, and have luckily taken Lodgings neer my Mother, our first care must be, to conceal our Disguize; to that end, be sure you never speak to me otherwise than by the name of Sir: 'ware tripping.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Leave that to me, Sir; I was the first that thought of this Adventure, and if I can't manage it, may I never live to be marri'd, and that's no small Curse. I'll be so far from betraying the secret in publick, that even in private, when we are alone, you shall pass with me for what you seem.

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: My next endeavours must be, how to sute my own behaviour to what I intend, a Town-Gallant. In this, Franck, you must instruct me, for you have known the Town before you came to my service.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: True. First then, have you seen any of our new Plays?

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: Yes, I have read 'em all as they came out in Print.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Good: that will be a great help. For look ye, Sir, just as some raw Poets borrow their Scenes from the Fop-company they frequent, in the same manner, many raw Gallants square their behaviour to their Fop-scenes. What else makes these sort of Phrases so common, Dear heart— You understand me— Let me die— And all that—

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: For my own part, I don't know whether people in London talk thus or no; but if you'd have me discourse out of Plays, let me alone.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Besides this, you must be sure to be very confident, or if you please, impudent in all your actions: That's the prime Rule of Converse.

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: Gad take me, I cannot promise very much in that particular, but I'll endeavour.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Gad take me! Oh, fie, fie, I'm ashamed to hear ye; why that's an Oath for a Country-Schoolmaster: You must learn to swear more like a Gentleman, or you'll spoil a Gallant.

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: Why prethee, how swears a Gentleman? does not a Cobler swear as well?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: No, Sir, a Cobler swears at the second hand. To swear like a Gentleman, is to swear in a new Phrase, and with a full mouth. I know a Lady neer the place where I was born, that never encouraged her Children with Apples or Sugar-plums, but when they had invented some handsome new Oath, as, By my Mothers Maiden-head, or, By my Fathers dapple Mare; or rather than none at all, a Rapper would content her, so that it came in, in a right place, and had a good Emphasis. I have seen her little Imps of four or five years old swear as heartily for a Breakfast, as e're I heard our Chaplain pray.

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: But may not a man hope for an indifferent good Behaviour without such blunt downright Prophaneness?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: If you converse only with Ladies, indeed, why you may do pretty well if you have often, Gad Madam, and, As I hope to live Madam, and the like. But e'faith Sir, if you have to do with a Coach-man or a Mechanick, you must be at it with, Damn me ye Son of a Tinker, or you'll do no good.

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: Why Son of a Tinker?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Oh Sir, that's a new Phrase, and much more significant, than Son of a Whore: Alas, that's grown so common, as 'tis become a term of indearment, only to be used to Friends and Familiars; as what's more usual, than Dear Son of a Whore, how I love thee! No body's asham'd of Son of a Whore, but a Son of a Tinker is not company for a Footboy.— Then young Gentleman, can you Curse well?

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: Faith, Franck, I doubt, not.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Why there's it; yet you may perhaps when you're moved. But above all, have a care when any one offends you, not to cry A Pox take him, or The Devil take him, for these are (as I said before) Terms of Friendship. Is there any thing more ready, than A Pox take thee Jack, where hast thou been all this while? and for the other business, it is so innocent, we use it of our selves; as, The Devil take me, Sir, that's a good Iest.

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: 'Tis very true.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Therefore I think a more terrible way of Execration would be to say of your Enemy, May he never see his Mistriss's Eyes again; or May his Taylor never trust him: But this, Sir, I leave to your Discretion.

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: These are general Rules fit for all Companies and places. Now for my particular daily Exercise.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: That, Sir, must be divided betwixt Drinking—

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: I'm nought at that Weapon—

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Not so good as your Mother, I confess;— but I say you must spend the day in Drinking, Gaming, and Wenching: but in this last affair, you must not enter too far, for a reason that I know.

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: If I do, the Devil's in me. But prethee Frank, how must I spend the morning, which some call the sober part of the day?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Why there's your mistake: The morning is part of the night. A true Gallant should never wake 'till eleven, nor be drest 'till twelve at soonest.

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: Then what's to be done in the night?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: For the night, Sir, you must be sure never to go home 'till towards one; then in your way as you go, you must take occasion to beat two or three Watchmen, and break all the Windows that dare oppose ye.

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: This is something harsh, methinks, for a Learner: then to break windows shews too much like Confederacie with the Glasiers: and for a Gentleman to correspond with Mechanicks, is, I fancie, very odious.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: No matter what you fancie. There is, I confess, a milder way of Night-adventures; and that is, to pass the Watch, give 'em a shilling, abuse the Constable in clean Language, for which he'll thank ye: and instead of breaking windows, to serenade your Mistriss.—

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: No more. I'll serenade my Mother, this very night. Let it be your care to provide Musick; and for a Song or so, you can perform it as well as any Shepherdess in London.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Leave that to me, Sir: In the mean time look ye who comes yonder, to exercise your Courtship. ' Foregad, Mrs. Loveal, my old Lady's Woman, the easiest Quarry in the world to enter a young beginner. Go pick her up, and when you've tired that humour pretty well, I'll cross the way and meet you full i'the mouth, and so give you occasion to drop her.

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: Sweet Lady, your humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: O Lord, Sir, I'm in great haste.

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: Nay, if y'are in haste, I can be as hasty as you, and keep pace with ye, I warrant ye. I cannot in Conscience see such a Delicate, Little, Plump, Pretty, Young thing, and of such a Ravishing Air, walk the streets alone, as if disconsolate and forsaken of all mankinde: I'faith, Madam, you must not therefore refuse me both the Honour and Satisfaction to wait on ye.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, excuse me for that: I am but a Servant my self, and have been but now at the New Exchange to buy my Ladies things, who is new come to Town. I know, Sir, a Gentleman of your Quality cannot abase your self so much, to love such a one as I am.

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: Love, my Dear? never talk of that; for I must tell thee, my friend, and so forth, (as my Couzen Wildbloud has it) I am an exceeding Honourer of course Linnen; 'tis as proper sometimes in an under Garment, as a course Towel to rub and scrub me.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Pardon me, Sir, I vow you are such an obliging Gentleman— but I know my Lady expects me.

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: Never trouble your self; she has other affairs to think on. Look you, sweet Lady, here's a Tavern hard by, where we may have a very convenient Room, and be private. And I protest now, I'm so taken with your Discourse and Person, we cannot part with dry Lips, as they say.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Aye, Sir, but if my Lady should think me long.—

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: (aside) Defend me! she's more willing than I: do they call this Picking up?— This way, dear heart.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Sir, the next Tavern is downwards.

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: (aside) Now do I tremble all over, when I think what I want to satisfie her expectations. 'Slid, if I stay with her but three minutes longer, she'll finde where I'm defective, and then I'm ruin'd.— Aye, Madam, but there's a house this way that has better Accommodation: At some Taverns the Drawers are such Rascals, they'll peep, and be troublesome.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Well, Sir, I am a Stranger in Town, and therefore submit to your better experience.

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: (aside) Now this damn'd Frank, where is she?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Sir Thomas Whimsey, your most humble Servant.

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p:
Honest Rogue, how dost thou? come along with me;
I'll tell thee the best Jest.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: (Looking after them) Now, may I never live to see Darby-shire, and the well-meaning Country-Gentlemen again, if this be not a pitiful trick: The first man that ever made Love to me in London, serve me thus; offer me the Wine-tavern, and then run away, without taking his leave too? Now out upon him: I have been often deceived in my life, but never in so few words before. Sir Thomas Whimsey quoth a? well, my comfort is, I know no such Whimseys in the Country. There, if a young man offers Kindness to a young maid, he will go thorough-stich with it; which does the poor Soul good at heart. And— Oh me! it strikes two a clock. Madam I come, I come Madam, I come, I come.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: WHere's Dashwel?

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: At the Office, Sir.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: 'Tis well: Go bid my Niece come hither.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: This Niece of mine is much offended at her confinement; but it's no matter: she's young and handsome, and I am old and wary. If she be known broad, she'll quickly get a Husband, and that will be no small Nusance to my Estate: For though her Father devised her and 6000 l. to my tuition, with proviso, that if she marries without my consent, then to forfeit the said sum; Yet if she happens to be well marri'd, and without disparagement, what the Chancery may decree in this Case, I know not.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: Niece, I have considered of your grievances, which you moved at Dinner; but I perceive you are young, and do not weigh things with discretion. Should I suffer ye to go abroad, or let people come to ye, some vain idle fellow with a white Perriwig and a long Sword, would marry ye, Niece, d'you mind me? would marry ye; and then you're undone.— Look ye, Niece, Abundans cautela non nocet, pray observe that.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
In the mean time, Sir, the continual imprisonment of my Chamber is insufferable: I'm sure it is very prejudicial to my health;
and I'm troubled with such a Head-ach, flesh and bloud is not able to endure it.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: Nay, good Lucy, never talk of that, but consider the Maxime; A private damage is to be suffered, rather than a publick inconveniencie. Your distemper concerns only your self, Niece: But should I see you marri'd to one of those Fops I told you of but now, it would break my heart.—

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: (aside) Yes, no doubt, to part with her Portion.—

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: Yet because you shall not say I'm made of Marble, and have no consideration of your Infirmities, look ye, Niece, you and your Maid shall have a turn in the Temple-Garden this Evening, and there taste the sweet air of the Thames. What wou'dst thou have more, poor thing?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Besides, Sir, by reason of this strict life you impose upon me, I have forgot all the Education my Friends had heretofore given me.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: You would say, you have lost your Dancing; I understand ye: 'Tis no matter, a modest woman should not Dance well. You have not lost your Singing, I'm sure; yo'are often practising: yet it were better if you cou'd onely sing Psalms.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: What to do, Sir? you seldom let me go to Church.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: It is not necessary: You have good Books at home, read them: There's The whole duty of man; think of that, Niece, think of that.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: So I do, Sir, as much as possible I can; but—

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: 'Tis enough. I understand what you wou'd say; but you wou'd have some of these naughty Plays. Niece, I must tell ye, they are not good for ye, and let that suffice: Yet ye shall have variety, Niece. Look ye, I'll buy ye the Seven Champions, and I think, Dashwel has Clark's lives of Famous men; I'll borrow that of him, and you shall read that too: And for Education, you shall have enough, Lucy. I scorn it should be said that any of my Bloud should want Education. Dashwel shall teach ye French, he understands Littleton perfectly well: And if you please, I'll have a Master come and teach ye to cast Account, and write Short-hand.—

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Sir, here's Madam Goodfeild newly light out of her Coach, and coming up stairs.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p:
Away, Niece, here's a Client of Quality coming, and I
wou'd not have you seen in this dress for the world.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Is that your Master?

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Yes, Madam.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Mr. Docket, I am come now, only to tell you I cannot stay; I must only acquaint you with my business, and be gone again.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: First, Madam, let me bid you welcome. (Salutes her.) Now, Madam, if you please to sit by me, here in this Chair, I am for you.— Spruce, reach me Pen, Ink, and Paper, to take instructions.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: You must know then, good Mr. Docket, that I come to you with Commendations from my Lady Simple of Darbyshire.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, I know her very well: her Husband, old Sir Simon, late deceas'd, was the very first Client I ever had.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: God bless her good Ladyship, say I, for she's my good Neighbour; but let that pass: I love few words, Mr. Docket, and those to the purpose.—

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: My own humour directly.—

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: You must know then, Mr. Docket, that I have a one and only Daughter in the Country, her name is Elizabeth Goodfeild, (you may set her down, if you please) a wild Wench she is, and therefore 'tis high time to marry her, (but you need not set that down.) Now, Sir, my good Lady Simple has but one Son, who since his Fathers death, is Sir Alexander Simple, (pray set him down;) and my Lady Simple and I considering that 'tis better to wed over the Mixon, than over the Moor, as they say in our parts, (but you need not set that down.) Therefore, Mr. Docket, we two Mothers, like loving Neighbours, have concluded to marry together.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: You mean your Children, but I understand ye: Very good.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: My Lady Simple, Sir, is very badly handled with the Gout, that's the plain truth on't; and therefore she can't travel: And for Sir Alexander, he being the only Sprig of the Family of the Simples remaining, we were not willing to venture him to such a naughty Town; he might not only have been spoil'd himself, but done my Daughter no good too. For you know, Mr. Docket, Husband and Wife are but one flesh.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: 'Tis very true, Madam, there's a scurvy Disease here in Town, which many a man gets, besides the Simples.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: To conclude, Sir, I am intrusted of all hands, to come to you, as my Lady Simples Lawyer, to take care with you that my Daughter be well feofft in something: For the truth is, Mr. Docket, her Father, honest Justice Goodfeild, before he died, set her a very good Portion, namely 5000 l. which you know requires a good Joynture.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: For that, Madam, let me alone; but will you have it by way of Uses, Feoffment, Bargain and Sale, Lease and Release, Fine and Recovery, or how? The usual way, is by way of settlement to certain Uses; but then I must know the names of your Feoffees in trust: And here Madam, there needs no Livery nor Attornment.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: For my part, I understand not a word you say: but here's your Fee, Mr. Docket; and I'll send Steven Trupenny—

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Sir, here's Mr. Truman, without.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: Let him attend, and do you bear him company.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: And as I was saying, Sir, I ll send my Steward Stephen True-penny to ye; he can draw Bonds and Conditions, and he'll acquaint you with the very inside of this business. In the mean time you see I cannot stay now: I go hence to visit a Nephew, a Turkie Merchant in the City, with whom I sup; but I sha'not fail to be at my Lodgings within an hour after Sun-set, at furthest.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: Then, Madam, give me leave to wait upon you at your Return, and at the same time I'll consult with your Steward about this Affair.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Sir, you shall be heartily welcome. I have two or three Bottles of Darby there, which I brought up in my Coach, (for I hate your London-Drink) you'll say when you taste it, 'tis the best you ever drank. Till then, God be with you, good Mr. Docket, I shall not fail to be at home.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: I'll wait on ye to your Coach, Madam.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: To one Sir Alexander Simple, sayst thou?

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: But is her Daughter in Town?

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: No; the two young people remain with the old Gouty Lady in the Country.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: There's the Devil.—

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: But I have better news for you, Sir; Madam Lucia and her Maid have leave to be in the Temple-Garden this Evening.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: That's well.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: And her Maid bid me take care to let you know it.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: That's better: I will not fail to meet her.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Whist; not a word more, as you hope to be Knighted.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: Mr. Truman, I sent for you, this morning, by my man.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: You did Sir, and you see I'm come according to the Summons.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: Yo'are welcome. Look ye, Mr. Truman, you and I have often treated about this Mortgage. I have now considered of it; and you shall know my resolution in few words. Look ye, Mr. Truman, I will not have you say that Summum jus est Summa injuria. Therfore mind me, Sir: you know you owe me 6000 l. Principal.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Well, Sir.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: Besides this, there is above 300 l. due for Interest, and about 200 l. farily reckon'd for Costs which I have been at in outing your Tenants, and recovering quiet Possession of your Estate; that's 500 l. Now observe me, Mr. Truman, I ll pay you down 500 l. more upon the Nail; all which Sums amount to 7000 l. And for this, you shall confirm the Estate to me and my Heirs for ever, with a General Warranty contra omnes gentes, and pass a Fine of the said Estate, Come ceo que il ad de son done. And so you and I will continue good friends, Mr. Truman.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: So in effect, you will have an Estate of 500 l. a year in the best Lands in Hartfordshire, all improvable, with 100 Acres of Timber, and all this for 7000 l. And so you and I shall continue good Friends.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: As any live, I protest.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Never upon these Conditions, I assure ye. Look ye, Mr. Docket, you would have me confirm the Estate above-said, upon the Conditions aforesaid.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: Aye.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Nay mind me, Sir; you would have me pass a Fine upon the said Estate, with Warranty to you and your Heirs for ever.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: Aye.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: First the Devil shall have you and your Heirs for ever; observe me, Mr. Docket. And besides this, I would have ye take notice, and if you think fit, ye may put down the Memorandum in your Almanack; I will take in my Mortgage within two days, and that malgré your damn'd Worship, and all your Confederates in Hell, d'you mind me? And so farewel, Mr. Attorney Docket.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: Oh, farewel Huff, if y'are so impatient.
sp.l: Go, spend your grease, vain Fop, fret, swell, and vex:
I laugh at idle words, with Currat Lex.

div.head: SCENE I.
The Temple Garden.

sp.speaker: N. Good.
sp.p: HEre's no appearance of the Game you expect.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: No matter: It is yet too early. I confide in my intelligence; my Lawyer's Clerk never fail'd me.

sp.speaker: N. Good.
sp.p: Is your Correspondent that dull Beast that brought you the Message from his Master this morning?—

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Oh Plague on him, no: Mine is a brisk fellow that has Sense and Ingenuity in him. All of the Tribe are not like Dashwel and Docket; if they were, here would be no living among 'em: They would infect the Town worse than the Sickness, or Pox.— In the mean time, Ned, you little think what your good Mother comes up about.

sp.speaker: N. Good.
sp.p: Hast thou learnt that? prethee tell me—

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Not so hasty; the News is not so welcome. You must know then, Mr. Edward, that your old woman has agreed with another old woman in the Country, to match your Sister to her Son; and she has now made this Journey to dispatch the settlements of Marriage, and so forth: So that my Interest in the party aforesaid, is dwindled to nothing.

sp.speaker: N. Good.
sp.p: D'you know the Son's name?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Yes; Sir Alexander Simple—

sp.speaker: N. Good.
sp.p: 'Tis enough. Remember that I tell ye, Iack, it lies not in the power of Fate to make up the Match. The old people may please themselves in talking, but 'tis the young ones must do in these cases. I know Simple well enough; he has a large Estate indeed, but is the veriest Coxcomb in ten Counties. And for my Sister, I am sufficiently assured, she'd rather come to London and sell Oranges, than marry him, of all the Cullies in England.— But who are these?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: This is the Lady, Ned, into whose good Graces I must introdue thee. What thinkst thou of her?

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: She seems a delicate Creature, and full of Sweetness. Let us engage 'em.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: I thought I should not stave ye off. Allons.— Madam Lucia! I know not to what kind Star I owe this happiness; but to see you here, compleats my joys.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Mr. Truman, your Servant. You are always in this strain— What Gentleman is that?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: My very particular Friend. Let me beg you, Madam, to gratifie his ambition with the favour to kiss your fair hand.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Being your friend, Sir, he has sufficient merit to commend him to the most noted Beauty of the Town. You pass too great a Complement on me, I assure ye, Mr. Truman.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Your pardon, Madam. As to be noted, is not always to be a Beauty, so I finde, to be the most noted Beauty, is not to be the Greatest or the best. Witness your self: it is in your example, Madam, I perceive, that Fame neither speaks always truth, nor all truths.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Nay, Gentlemen, never railly me in this manner: I'd rather you would call me ugly in plain intelligible expressions, than laugh at my ill face in you fine Language. My Glass tells me what I am, better than all the Courting Monsieurs 'twixt Ludgate and the Abby.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Oh, Madam, Ladies are no Competent Judges of their own Beauty.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: They alwaies value it too much, or too little.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
On the other side, Gallants that are always praising their
Mistrisses Beauty, at the same time dispraise their own Wit.. 'Tis to be presumed, their Common-place runs all on that Subject and they have no other matter to discourse of.— Therefore, if you please, Gentlemen, we'll talk of something else.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: (aside to Truman) Oh how I love her for this! her Wit is equal to her Face.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Faith, Madam, let us improve the time as well for action as discourse; let us all to the Park this inviting Evening: My Coach will be ready in three minutes.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Mr. Truman, you speak like a stranger to my condition. I am but a Prisoner at large, and my Fetters reach not farther than this. Garden.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: All Curses on the damn'd Geaolor, your Uncle.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Mr. Truman, I have always lookt upon you as my friend.— Alas, I have but few.— (weeps) My Consinement is a Disease▪ and I fear will prove my death.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Madam, this Gentleman and I, have but one heart: Either direct us how to serve you, or be pleased to submit▪ to our advice, and I'll secure your Liberty before to morrow-night, that Devil of an Uncle shall no longer abuse such Innocence.

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: Observe, Frank; is not that my Brother, so busie with yonder Lady?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Yes I vow, or my eyes are the veriest Lyers in London.

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: What a Devil makes he in Town? he's as great a stranger here as I am. When we left the Country, was not he at Cambridge?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: We all thought so: As sure as can be, this is some Mistriss. But what's he that stands with him?

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: He seems much a Gentleman. I'm resolved to make one of the Company: My Brother can never know me in this Disguise. Have among'e, e'faith.— Gallants, are ye for Love alone, Conversation alone, or Love and Conversation together?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Why, young Bully?

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: If ye are for Love alone, I'll leave the Lady to ye, and Bien proface Messieurs. If ye are for Conversation alone, why then Gentlemen, pray learn to be civil, and you two go together by your selves; 'tis rude to stay here, and over-hear our discourse, when the Lady and I would be private.—

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: This is the maddest young Raskal I ever saw in my life.

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: But if ye are for Love and Conversation together, why then, faith, let us share the blessed Community; here are four men to two women: A good proportion for Town-Ladies; two to two is only fit for Nuns that have vow'd Chastity: But I hope, Madam, you are not so vain to think of that.—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Away, rude fellow.—

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Belike you think your self a man then. Alas, poor thing, thou art below a kicking;— but be gone, or—

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: Not so fast, Sir; be I man or boy, or whate're I am, I wou'd have thee know, Bully-hec, I am able to give satisfaction to any man in the Bed of Honour.— No more huffing. If you are minded to speak to me By the way of Bilbo (as the Play has it) I'll answer ye by the way of Dangerfeild. Hark ye—

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Nay, never urge me, I swear I will not: it is not handsome to tell Names.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Alas poor Creature, thou dost not understand what belongs to a Waiting-Damsel; it is part of her office to discover her Lady's Secrets. I perceive by this, thou art but a Callow-maid— and o'my Conscience a Virigin.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: A Virgin? Aye, a pure one.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Fie, fie, Sweet-heart, learn more behaviour; though perhaps, you are such, you should not acknowledge it. Shou'd you talk thus before Company, you'd be laught at for being so out o'the Mode. A Maidenhead of this bigness? out upon't!

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Now, fie upon you; y'are the strangest man, I ever talkt with.

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: — And without Seconds; if you fail, I'll post ye for a Coward: I know your name; Goodfeild.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Spare your provocations. I'll meet thee, though thou wert the Devil in the shape of a Boy: as thou mayst be for ought I know, by thy intelligence.

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: Well, Sir, now you and I have agreed, I am your very humble Servant. In the next place, I must borrow a few words of your friend that stands yonder, so like a civil Gentleman, and has not a word to say for himself.

div.stage: B. Good▪ and Truman come forward, the rest walk farther off.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: With me? What would the Child have with me? Come, speak thy mind quickly, little fellow, thou feest I am engaged.

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: You would say, with Monsieur Palamede, that T'are a man of business: Yes, no doubt on't. I suppose; sweet Sir, you are one of those hard Students, whose delight is continually to affront Littleton and the Law, by writing Farce, to be laught at by the Player-women en Chivalier; or else en Debauché to hussah for a Wench, be perpetually drunk, and break your friends windows that go to bed before ye.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: So: And this you suppose my Character?

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: Yes: with only this Addition: Yo'are a man of a very excellent temper, you are not easily provoked neither to Anger nor Raillery. Come, shall I answer for you? As sure as can be, you either wou'd or shou'd say, Sweet young Gentleman, or Sweet Sir, or Plain Sir, or something to that purpose; You see I have been lately discoursing with a Lady, and as I hope to breathe now, she has drawn me so dry, and all that— I have not Language enough left me to say, Your Servant, Sir.— Come, Sir, confess ingenuously, wou'd you not have said thus, if you cou'd?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Said thus; quoth a? why thou sayst so fast, thou wou't not let me say a word in thy presence.— What a Devil art thou? whence com'st thou? thou art the pertest little thing I ever met with.

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: Perhaps, Sir, I have wrong'd ye, and ye are a Wit. For (as the Play says) All Wits have their failings, and have the fortune to be thought Fools one in their lives; and who knows but this is your critical minute?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: So, so; thou art a very forward stripling, and dost begin betimes to be bolder than welcome. Thou mayst thank thy Childhood for this Liberty: If thou wert a man, I should talk to thee in another Dialect.

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: Then it seems, Sir, you can talk to a man, though not to a boy: but can you talk to a woman? Suppose me a woman a little, though As arrant a Fruit-woman as any is in Rome; de grace Monsieur, how would you behave your self?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Away, Boy; if thou hast any business with me, dispatch it: Time's precious, and I can waste no more.

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p:
Nay, never mince the matter. If I were a woman, I know what you'd do. First of all, you'd pelt me with two or three little pretty deux yeux: Then off goes the Hat, thus, and out
comes the Comb, thus; and after having friskt o're the bottom of your Perriwig a little, and exalted the foretop thus, you would make Love according to the latest 〈◊〉, thus— Sweet Lady, you have here a man to your minde: For to confess the truth to you, I can but counterfeit Love to try you. Gad, Madam, I never yet could love any woman: and since I have seen you, and I do not, I am certain now I shall scape for ever.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Why thou art a very impudent fellow to talk of things so much above thee. Alas, poor childe! thou dost not understand what belongs to Love, nor won't these seven years.

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: Forbear such frightful words; I am not so young, wise Sir, 〈◊〉 I understand what Love is. 'Tis the seducer of Virtue, the disturber of Quiet, the madness of Youth, the dotage of old Age, the enemy to good Humour, and, as the Play says very well, The reason of all unreasonable Actions.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: And is this all you know of Love?

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: No: Love was thus from the beginning; our Grandfathers know as much as this. In our Age the face of Love is very much alter'd. Our Gallants have wisely considered Love has been made so common, trite, and out of fashion, that, though there is something belonging to the thing that is very useful and much affected, yet the damn'd Name is hateful; and both Sexes have agreed, though their designes be never so sensual, to disown the scandal of Love, and call it Gallantry, Mirth; and Raillery. Love, out upon't! 'tis got into all places, though never so improper and abusrd. Have ye not Love in a Maze, Love in a Tub, Love in a Wood, nay, Love in a Nunnery and Love in a Pipkin?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Hold a little, I thou everlasting Talker; I think I must stop thy mouth: Let me view thee well; things of thy age, are not usually thus witty. I begin to love thy humour.—

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: Then, Woe. woe to poor Benito, I sinde my abundance of Wit has ruin'd me. Dare you name Love, when yo've heard me declare so much against it? Farewel, Sir— (Is going, but turns again. Yet if you have Courage enough to be Loves Champion, I desie you upon't; and will attend you to morrow-morning at five, neer Lambs-Conduit, if you dare meet me.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: I dare.

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: Adieu then, Iusque a revoir.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Nay, but one word more; stay a little—

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: Not a moment: I never talk with Enemies. Your are engaged: Look, your company expects you.— Come Frank.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: What hast thou been doing all this while, Iack, with that Boy?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: 'Tis a witty Impertinent, and Raillies well.— But how go affairs with you? what have you resolved on?

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Faith, we are not come to Resolutions, but so far from that point, that this Lady is pleas'd to refuse whatever I propose. She is too much her own enemy, and too great a friend to something that looks like Honour, to admit us to serve her.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Excuse me, Sir, you have obliged me much in such generous offers, but I have many Reasons not to use 'em. Mr. Truman, you are best acquainted with my condition, and therefore can best judge of what I tell ye. Should I leave my Uncle, (though his usage is both unhandsome, and unnatural) I shall not onely loose my Fortune, for my Father has committed both me and it to his Arbitration.—

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Madam, I value not your Fortune, I am already Master of so liberal an Estate, I care not to encrease it. If you please to make me happy in your person, I'll venture loosing, what your Uncle covets.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: That, Sir, is the least of all my thoughts: And had I not, that to think on, yet I can ne're consent to leave so neer a Relation, to whose Government my dying Father gave me, without, not only his Consent, but Knowledge: And that too, with two young men. This, Gentlemen, (although I do not question in the least your Honour) is so very scandalous, I never can admit it.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Your Uncle has justly forfeited his Trust, abusing it: and, Madam, you may well be confident your Father never fanci'd him for such a Guardian, when he first named him yours.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Sir, I not doubt it. And though I sigh for death or a more pleasing life,— yet I had rather ever continue thus wretched as I am, than be made happy, by any means that gives the least offence or prejudice to the spotless Fame of an innocent Maid.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: In the mean time, Madam, will you make me so happy as to let me hope I may hereafter be admitted to your service when you shall be a more absolute Mistris of your self, and free from the constraint of such a Guardian?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Provided, Sir, you use no violent means to accomplish such a freedom. I am not so ungrateful to forget a friendship, nor yet so dull as not to apprehend who has obliged me.— But Gentlemen, no more.— You must not know me: This is one of my Uncle's Spies.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Mistris Lucia, my Master desires to be recommended to you, and has sent me to conduct you home; he and I are just going forth about business, and he desires to see your Ingress before our Egress.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: So: Have ye any other Commendations from your Master?

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Non sum Informatus: That is to say, in English, He gave me no farther Instructions.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Then come along.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Mr. Dashwel, your humble Servant: Pray, Sir, quota cloka?

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Sweet Sir, I think it is neer octa hora: Your Servant Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Farewel Cods-head.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Now, Ned, what dost thou think of this Lady?

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: I think so well of her, that I think the worse of thee for bringing me acquainted with her to no purpose.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Why to no purpose?

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: You see she admits not my Addresses.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Thou art a Fool, Ned; and though thou hast studied so long at the University, thou art very illiterate in Women. Why all her discourse was nothing but I will and I won't: and when they are once arrived at that, they need but little Courting.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: I perceive thou art very learned in this sort of Philosophy, Iack: I think I had best get thee to read to me.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p:
Read, quoth a? no faith it needs not, I have it all by heart. In the first place, you must know, Friend mine, Women are not now so dull, and unapprehensive, as in former Ages: For just as times and seasons change, so Behaviour grows more polite; of which, the particular we discourse of, is one of the chief Examples. Antiently Girls had such a gross Education, that most of them knew neither to read, Bawdry; nor write, Assignations; their Parents
not caring to improve their judgment to be more capable than to distinguish betwixt their Husbands Doublet and Breeches; which not only made them ashamed to demand what most they wanted, but also when they had occasion to do so, or so,— Gad, they durst not, though one and twenty years old, without their Mothers leave.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: But in this Age—

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Aye, Ned, in this Age they begin to refine their Behaviour, and have found out the way of speaking, and yet not say a word.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: How Iack? to speak, and not say a word? that's a xsstrong Line.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: No matter, Ned, you have us'd to such at the place from whence you come. I say, they can speak their minde, and yet not say a word. And besides this, when they speak, they have invented such a delicate Language, that they will talk with you an hour together, and all the while discover a sence quite different from their words. The advantages they have acquired from Habits and Dress, to supply the defects of Nature in spite of mankinde, I'll omit.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Aye, prethee do: 'Tis a Subject only proper to Taylors and Tyre-women.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: By the way, Ned, I must tell thee, I am of opinion, the Mystery of Dress is now arrived to its utmost perfection; and must of necessity, like the Roman Empire, decay in after-Ages.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Thou talk'st high, Iack.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Not so high as the Ladies Toors. I tell thee, Ned Goodfeild, 'tis a frightful thing to see some women, that pass for Beauties in due time and place, undress'd: I do not mean naked; but only their face without the Toor, Shades, Locks, Hollows, Bullies, and some transitory Patches.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: But to let all this pass for this time. You observed the young fellow was here but now?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Aye, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Is he not some little Bully here about Fleetstreet?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: No: I know 'em all, but never saw his eyes before: But why all these inquiries?

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Nothing; but the little Wasp has challenged me, and I'm to meet him to morrow-morning at four, in Redlyon-fields.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Why this is the maddest Rogue I e're heard of. He has challenged me too, to be at five, neer Lambs-Canduit. Belike, Ned, he makes nothing of thee; he has done thy business in imagination, and has chosen me for a second course to Breakfast. Two Duels in a morning are pretty fair, for such a young beginner.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: I rather think he'll meet neither on's. I fancie he neither lookt nor spoke like a Fighter. However, I'll not venture the disgrace of failing in such an occasion. I'm resolved to observe the place and time appointed.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: And I. 'Tis possible the Encounter may be pleasanter than we imagine. I am much of thy opinion, Ned: He did not at all behave himself like a Killer of men.—

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: But hark ye, Iack, you must not be seen with me, for I'm to meet without Seconds.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: No fear of that: I have another field appointed, at sufficient distance.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Come, let's go finde out some Company and be merry. This Garden is unpleasant, now the Lady's gone.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: Enter a Boy conducting Docket and Dashwel.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: BE pleas'd, Sir, to repose a while in the Dining-room: I expect my Lady's Return every minute.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: Well said: But hark ye, Youth, is Mr. Trupenny about the house?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, he's a writing above in his Chamber.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: Prethee, Sweet-heart, tell him here's one Docket desires to see him.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: D'you hear, Young man? Mr. Docket of Cliffords-Inn: You must ever give things their due Addition.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Well, Sir.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: Hast thou brought thy Inkhorn with thee, Tom?

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Yes, yes, Sir, vouz avez the Inkhorn, look ye, Sir, but— alas, I've forgot my Almanack.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: No matter, man, if thou hast any Paper about thee?

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: O Lord, Sir, I put a whole Quire of Copying-paper in my Pocket, and here's two Quills—

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: Nay, perhaps we may have no occasion to use 'em.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: But you know, Sir, it's good to be sure.— Look ye, Sir, here comes Mr. Trupenny. I vow he looks like a very understanding man, and one that can do business: I wonder whether he can write Court-hand.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: Mr. Trupenny, your Servant.

sp.speaker: Trup.
sp.p: Your most humble Servant, good Mr. Docket; I am heartily glad to see ye at our Quarters: And I vow you're very welcome, as I may say.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: Sir, I thank you. Here's I and my man Dashwel are come to wait upon your Lady, about a little Concern of hers; I suppose, Sir, you're no stranger to it.

sp.speaker: Trup.
sp.p: No, Sir; my Lady order'd me to draw up the particulars of Sir Alexander Simple's Estate, which are to pass into my young Mistriss Betty's Joynture. I have been at it e're since she went out; and here 'tis in Writing: Look ye, Sir, mine's but an indifferent Hand.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: Good enough, Mr. Trupenny, good enough. Let me see; here's the Mannor of— uh; and the Mannor of— uh; with the Advouson appurtenant— Appendant you mean; but I understand ye. Then here's 600 Acres of Pasture, and 400 Acres of Meadow— O fie, that must not be, you must always put Pratum before Pastura: Remember the old Verse as long as you live, and you'll never do amiss: Messuagium, Toftum, &c. Dashwel shall gi't you in writing.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Trup.
sp.p: I thank ye most kindly, good Sir; I'll do as much for you at any time.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: Then here's— All, and all manner of Commons thereunto belonging, In quodam loke vocate be peak juxta Podex Diaboli, anglicè the Devil's Britch.— Well, Sir I understand ye: I'll e'en take these parcels home with me, and put 'em into due order, and so we'll proceed. I suppose, Mr. Trupenny, you'll submit to me, as for Form and false Latine?

sp.speaker: Trup.
sp.p: I Sir, and reason good. Form and false Latine, Mr. Docket? why, if it had not been for that, we need not ha'come to London. Our Curate might a made the Joynture well enough, but only for Form and false Latine.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: Mr. Trupenny, pray will you instruct me in one thing?

sp.speaker: Trup.
sp.p: With all my heart, Sir, if I can: But it's a likely matter that I shou'd instruct your Wordship in any thing, that have been bred all your life-time at the Inns of Chancery.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: O Sir, you are pleas'd to say so. But pray, Mr. Trupenny, what was Justice Goodfeilds Christen-name?

sp.speaker: Trup.
sp.p: Anthony, Sir; and I vow to ye, Mr. Docket, it was great pitty it was not Sir Anthony: For though he was but a Justice of Peace and Coram, so that he could a brought Rogues Coram nobis at any time, yet he might a been a Knight, and a good one, both for his Estate and Wit..

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: Indeed?

sp.speaker: Trup.
sp.p: Sir, Let me tell ye; There is my young Master Edward, who is now at Cambridge, God bless him, and send him well at age, for he lacks not much now. Mr. Docket, he will have about a three months hence, 800 a year, good Rents; and after his Mothers death, 600 a year more, which is her Joynture.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: (aside) Dashwel, what think ye, if I strike in with this Widdow, ha, Tom?

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Innuendo Widdow Goodfeild, Sir? I protest that wou'd be excellent.

sp.speaker: Trup.
sp.p: I have the value of all their Estate to a penny, in my books at home. Besides this, their Tenants are able men, and special Pay-masters; and indeed, my Lady does oblige 'em to it: For every Christmas she calls 'em all to dinner at the Hall: Then have we the Bagpipes, and are so passing merry.— But look ye, Sir, here comes my Lady her self: I knew she cou'd not tarry long out, after Sun-set.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: O. Mr. Docket, y'are welcome. I doubt I've made you expect me too long— But I protest now, I've had such a life since I saw you; I'll go no more into the City an God ' ill.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: Why, I pray, Madam?

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p:
Aw Lord, Sir, there is such doings— Here Loveal, take my Scarf— And then, Sir, there are such Cruel noises, all along the streets as you go, I dare say, it would make ones heart ake to hear'em. There was a woman, and she cri'd old Stockins, and ends a Gold and Silver; and a little further I met a fellow crying old Shoos and
Brooms. For my part, I could not ha'thought that old thing had been worth whistling for in this Town, where there is so much Pride and Ranting.— Come, Mr. Docket, pray take a feat by me here.— But that which will never out of my head, no I shall carry it to my grave wi'me, was some-body that stood just behinde my Coach, and cri'd— what was it Loveal?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Mackerel, Madam.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Aye, Mackerel. Mr. Docket, if you will believe me, it made so hideous a Din, it frighted me out of my place full upon Loveal that fate o're against me; and had it not been a great mercie, I had broke her face.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: Pray, Madam, were you never in Town before?

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, once; but I was very young then. It was when I was new marri'd to Squire Goodfeild: he brought me up to see the Fashion, and have a new Gown made, and so we went down again. But to proceed, Sir, beside the noises, here are such ugly smells in every corner— O, Loveal, did you observe the fine Gentlewoman that light out of the Coach with the Gentleman at the end of the long street, as we turn'd down the narrow lane by the new Church?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: D'you mean her, Madam, with the great black Toor, and face all spotted, with the Flowr'd-sattin Petticoat laced up almost as high as—

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Aye, aye, she: I warrant she's nought— But as I was saying, Mr. Docket, your smells, here in London, are most wickedly bad: I have been told, the occasion is your Sea-coal; but I rather think 'tis the sins of your naughty City, that makes it stink above ground. Had not you Londoners better come down to Darbyshire and fetch of our Coal from the Pits, which is (though I say it) a delicate Fewel, and almost as sweet as green Ash?

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: Indeed, Madam, the Town is offensive to most strangers, in these cases; but if you were to be demorant here a while, that is, to live among us, you would quickly be familiar with these things, which otherwise are troublesome to one that Discontinues the Visinage.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Oh, Mr. Docket, never talk of that; I wou'd not live in London, to be Lady Mayoress,— But now I think on't, ha'you done any thing in my Daughters business yet?

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, Mr. Trupenny has gi'n me sufficient Instructions for the Conveyance, before your Ladyship made your Entry.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: I'm glad on't with all my heart; there's so much time saved. Now have we nothing to do, but to be merry— Steven— She whispers. Exit Trupenny. Enter Trup. & Boy with Bottles and Glasses. Mr. Docket, gi'me your hand: I vow yo'are heartily welcome. Come, Sir, you shall taste a glass of our Country-ale, famous all o'er England— Come, Boy, fill out— observe how it flowers and sparkles: They talk of Canary, but there's no Canary in England like it. Well, I say nothing: the proof of the Pudding's i'the eating— Sir, my Service to ye, remembring my good Lady Simple, and all our Friends in Darbyshire.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: With all my heart, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Come, Sir, You and I'll go into the next Room, where I can entertain ye with more liberty.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Aye, with all my heart; I vow I'm under Coverture, as 'twere, while in my Masters presence.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Here, Boy, fill— I protest I had all sorts of your London-Wine at Supper to night, and it has lain something heavy at my stomach; but this glass of Ale has done me as much good as a cup of Aqua Mirabilis.— Give it Mr. Docket.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: Mr. Trupenny, here's to ye— My Lady Simple's good Health.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Come, Steven, sit down and drink with us.— Mr. Docket, I hate to keep over-much state with my Steward: There is a time when Ladies may be familiar with their Servants, an they were never so high and haughty.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: 'Tis very true, Madam.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Aye, Aye, haughty looks must be humbled sometimes, as well as others.— Mr. Docket, d'you take any Tobacco?

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: Yes, Madam; but I fear the smell may be a Nocument to you.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: What do you mean by that, Sir?

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: Madam, I mean, it may be a Nusance to ye; that is, it may offend ye.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p:
Oh, not at all, Sir: nay, you shall see I can bear you company. Boy, fetch some Pipes and a Light; I have my Box about me. Exit Boy, and Enter again with Lights and Pipes.
For my part, Mr. Docket, I'll tell ye truly, I was advised to it three or four years ago, for a certain infirmity; and indeed I have continued it ever since, and finde a great deal of good by it. It comforts the Stomack, warms the Heart, and cheers the Brain: And then for Rheum, 'tis an excellent drier.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: Nay, Madam, here are women in Town that take Tobacco.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: I but they run into a corner to do it, as if they were a going to be nought— Steven, fill me a Pipe— For my part, I am downright honest: I hate dissimulation. Come, come, there's no shame to take it: 'tis neither sinful, nor unlawful. I say, let your women in London be ashamed to take other things, and 'twould be better for 'em— But, Mr. Docket, you don't tell me how you like my Ale.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: 'Tis excellent Drink indeed, Madam.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Has it not a rare Farewel with it? Nay, 'tis brew'd in my own house, and I see to the working it my self: I put nine Strike to the Hogshead, I prorest—

sp.speaker: Trup.
sp.p: And as good Mault as any in the Country; though I say it: and that's a bold word.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Come, t'other Glass, and then we'll taste our Tobacco— pray, Sir, make use of my Box— Where stands the Ale? Fie, Steven, d'you let your Drink die in your hands? put it about, man, put it about.

sp.speaker: Trup.
sp.p: Madam, my Service to ye.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Well said. Mr. Docket, have at ye: Whose Health shall this be?

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: Madam, I seldom use to drink Healths.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: O, Sir, two or three will do ye no harm, in a civil way, I'll secure ye— Come, God bless his Majesty— (drinks) here, boy, fill.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: Gently, good Youth.— Mr. Trupenny, his Majesty's Health to ye. (drinks) Madam, I've done ye right.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: You have, Sir: Now gi't Trupenny, and reach the Candle.— Come, Sir— light your Pipe— (she lights, and speaks as she takes.) Let me tell ye— Mr. Docket— this is a Pipe of— good— Tobacco— ' Tis. the very best sort of— Virginia— and that's better— than Spanish— (Trupenny, lend me your stopper)— what think ye, Mr. Docket?

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: Indeed, Madam— I think it— is very— excellent— To— bacco— and has no— fault— unless it be— a little too— hot in the— mouth.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: The better for that, Sir— but I pray, Mr.— Docket— are you— a marri'd man?—

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: (bowing) No, Madam— I am a— Batchelour— at your Service.—

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Aw Lord, Sir,— here Truepenny, pick this Pipe; it don't come worth a Rush.— I vow, Mr. Docket, you are a very staid Batchelour, and have liv'd a single man a long time: but I doubt you ha'n't been honest all this while.— Boy, fill a glass of Ale. Come Sir, you shall give me leave to begin your Mistriss's Health.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: Ah, Madam!

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Here, Trupenny.— (drinks) I am confident, Mr. Docket, she must be very deserving Lady for whom you have waited thus long: And no doubt but you'll meet with some vertuous body that will reward all your patience at the long run, ne're fear it, Sir. For my part, I have been a Widdow now these eight years and upwards, and yet 'tis possible I may marry again before I die: The truth is, I have made no vow against it.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: Ah, Madam!—

sp.speaker: Trup.
sp.p: Mr. Docket, your Lady's good health, Sir. (drinks) Look ye, Super Naculum.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: Sir, I thank ye.— Now, young man, give it me, and fill it lustily. So; Mr. Trupenny, with my Lady's leave here, I'll begin to you—

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Nay, Mr. Docket, first pledge your Mistriss's Health, before ye begin a new one. I love fair drinking, and fair dealing with all my heart: For my part, I can't dissemble.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: Why then, Madam, there 'tis.— (drinks) Now, Madam, after all this, suppose a man shou'd—

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Take t'other Pipe?

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: No, Madam; make a motion to your Ladyship.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: To me, Sir? pray what is't?

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: Why, Madam, nothing but— Sweet-heart, prethee gi'me t'other Glass; I'll have one Health more, and then I'll tell ye. Methinks I begin to be very cheerful. Ha, ha, ha, I can't chuse but laugh at the Jest: this is call'd in our Law, Idemptitate nominis. Ha, ha, ha,— Madam, here's your Ladyships good Health, and I with it were a Sea to the bottom; Mr. Trupenny, here's to ye.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Sir, you oblige me.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p:
Now, Madam, I'll tell ye. You see, Madam, I'm a Batchelor,
and you see withal that your self are a Widdow. Faith, Madam, what think ye, if we two, to save charges, and the like, shou'd make but one Match on't? You see, Madam, I am plain.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: I like ye the better for that, Sir; plain dealing's a Jewel: But alas, alas, you can never pass this upon me.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: Why, pray Madam? d'you think I don't know what belongs to a Widdow?

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: D'you think I can imagine, Sir, that a man of your practice wou'd ever think of marrying such a one as I am?

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: Nay, never talk of that: but gi'me your hand on't, Widdow. You see the worst o'me. Come, shall it be, I Daniel take thee Mary?

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Soft Sir, Two words to a Bargain.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: Then consult thy Pillow upon't, Widdow: You shall finde me reasonable.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir, that's the fittest place where to think of Marriage: But here's my hand, you shall know more of my minde to morrow. In the mean time, good night, Sir. Trupenny, wait upon Mr. Docket. Loveal.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: Nay, nay, here's my man: and besides that, look ye, I am not so drunk, but I can find the way home: therefore, Mr. Trupenny, you may stay, look ye.

sp.speaker: Trup.
sp.p: O pardon me for that, Sir; indeed I'll wait on ye home: I know what belongs to breeding.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: Well then, Widdow farewel 'till to morrow. Be sure ye think of me to night, and think well. If I imagin'd, d'you see, you'd think amiss, I'd stay all night, look ye, and correct your thoughts.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: No, no, Sir, no fear of that. Good night, good night.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: The Lawyer's drunk.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: No, not so; only a little fuddled. But this is for the honour of our Country, wench. An my Lord Mayor were here, and all his Aldermen, I'd serve 'em all so: 'Tis for the honour of Darbyshire.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Aye, Madam, and for the honour of our Sex too.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: True, Wench; what's a clock?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Past eleven, Madam.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: O me! 'tis late: let's hye to bed; I am not used to these late hours.

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: Enter B. Goodfeild, Frank, and Musitians.

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: HEre, Gentlemen, this is the Window. Range your selves here, and strike a sprightly Air. (Musick of Violins and Flageolets. So, enough— Now, Frank, the Song I gave ye.

div.stage: A SONG, Which ended, Loveal appears in the Balconey.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Gentlemen, my Lady is but just laid down in her naked Bed; but she remembers her Respects to ye, and has sent ye here half a Crown. She says, she knows Mr. Docket has sent ye on to welcome her to Town; and she acknowledges the Civility. Then, Gentlemen, here's a Shilling more of my good will: My Name's Loveal, and I am my Lady's Woman. I vow, it's the finest Musick I e're heard in my life, and much better than our Country Harp and Bagpipe: And then the Song was such a pretty thing, I'd give any thing for a Copy.— But 'tis late, and I can't stay. Farewel, Gentlemen, and hye ye to bed. Good night t'ye all; I wish ye well home.

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: Nay, but hark ye, Damsel.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: She's gone.— Ah, Plague! This Widdow don't know what belongs to Serenading.

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: She shou'd ha'come to the Balconey in her Night-gown, and cri'd, Who's that comes at this unseasonable hour to disturb my Quiet? Then I shou'd have answered in a dying Tone, 'Tis I, forsooth; and ha' laid all the blame upon Love. Then raising my voice, I shou'd a huft, Allons, Widdow; let me come in to ye, hand to fist. Then she thinking I had been drunk, shou'd ha' replied, (as another Play has it very well) No, Sir, no,— I wonder you have the confidence to ask me, when you were so rude to me the last time.—

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: But instead of this, she shews her Breeding, to keep her Bed, and ne're speak to a Gentleman at all. This is, A-la-mode de pais, Ierny.

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: Did not the Chambriere name one Docket, to whom her Lady ascribes this Civility?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Yes. What a Devil should he be?

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: I can't imagine. 'Tis no matter: Content the Musick,

sp.speaker: Frank,
sp.p: and follow me to my Lodging.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Here, my Masters, here's that will satisfie ye all. Go—
sp.l: March boldly home, Sirs, without longer staying.
Fear not the Watch, they'll spare ye for your playing.

lg.l: O the little delights that a Lover takes
To tell his dear Phillis how much he despairs;
How great are his Cares,
And how his heart akes!
Now praising, now blaming, now flattering Miss,
While all the fine story not stgnifies this.
Sure Love can't consist in ill Language and Railing?
To term Miss a Monster for Beauty and Parts,
The thief of mens hearts;
Nay, call her for failing
A Tyrant with all sorts of mischievous Arms,
And make us believe she's a Witch for her Charms.
Much better in my minde, though less like a Poet,
Is plainly to shew her, when in a Love-fit,
The meaning of it;
And let her to know it
In such Terms as Nature shall dictate and tell us,
And not like your scribling Fop-amorous fellows.

div.head: SCENE I.
A Field.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: LOok ye, Ned; this is the Champain where you are to do Feats: Mine lies a little lower. But still I see no appearance of our little Duellist. I'll stay a while with thee, 'till he begins to appear; and then I'll retire, and leave thee to his mercie.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Aye, aye, there's no great danger.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Hast thou got a Fighting sword on? 'Sbud, Ned, thou art not mad, to venture thy life with this?

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Come, waive this Raillery, and let's talk of something else.— Didst thou observe yesterday, what havock the little Rogue made among the Plays?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Aye, like Don Quixot among the Romances, for all the world.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Why, his discourse was almost all Dramatick.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: True: but I perceived withal, he did it a purpose; and not through any want of Invention, or defect in his own Genius, as your Country-Squire uses Wit's Common Wealth, and the Academy of Complements. For, sometimes you shou'd have him speak his own Sense, and that in very witty Terms too.— But, e'faith yonder he comes. I vanish: Farewel, Ned, take heed he hits you not in Tierce, when it shou'd be in Quart.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: So, now for my Gamester.

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, are ye here already? Well, I perceive you ride the Fore-horse: Yet methinks, ye don't look like one prepar'd for Fighting— Come, 'faith, what satisfaction will you give me to take up the Duel?

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Satisfaction, quoth a? thou talk'st as if I were in a posture to beg my life. Soft, Sir, it is not come to that yet.

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: No? why then belike you are resolved to fight? Come, Sir, unbutton.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Stay a little.—

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: Nay, then I perceive you are one of those that will not rend the Buttons from your Doublet for any man's pleasure; and with good Sir Nicholas, Your Conscience will not let you fight in a wrong Cause. I thought so at first.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: I tell thee, young Sir, thou art much mistaken: Thou sha't have fighting enough— but first you shall hear me—

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: Ad autre, ad autre, this Whedle won't pass. I see, you are minded to reverse the laudable course of the world; and instead of falling from Disputing to Fighting, you wou'd drill me from Fighting to Disputing; but this must not be among friends: Therefore, resolve, sweet Sir, either to give me Amende honorable, or fight. Chuse which you please: you see I am reasonable.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Oh, very reasonable!— I protest, it's a shame for a man to engage with such a little young Thing: and yet, I vow, I think I must be forc'd to chastize him when all's done.— Hark ye, Childe, d'you know what Amende honorable signifies?

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: Yes, very well. 'Tis only to confess your offence on your knees, and ask me pardon, in certain forms proper to that purpose. 'Tis a French Mode of satisfaction, and of great use among men of Honour.— Well then, you are willing to perform it?

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Not yet: Hold a little. First let me know how I've offended ye, and for what I must ask your pardon?

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: Uds bud, Sir, d'you come here only to ask Questions?— This is not to be endured: You have wasted my whole stock of Patience; and now you shall finde me as arrant a Lion, as if ye had call'd my Mistriss Son of a Whore.— Come, Sir, draw.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Must not we uncase then?

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: It's no matter; I'll fight you with your Coat on. O'my Conscience, there's no foul play under it.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Nay then, if ye are desperate, have at ye.

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: So, Sir, to your Guard— Good.— I use always, before I begin a Duel, to throw off my Perriwig. 'Tis troublesome in fighting. (Discovers her self. Come, Sir, advance. Why don't ye come on? ye see I lie open.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: — Sister—

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: — Brother—

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: I the name of wonder, what make you at London?

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: Nay, rather, what make you at London?

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: And why in this Disguize?

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: You shall first answer me; By my Virginity you shall. You know what the Play says, For Decencie, the man should offer first.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: My Tale is quickly told. I grew weary of Cambridge, and came hither to give my self the Divertisements of the Town. I have been here but three days, and yesterday my very good friend helpt me to a Mistriss, with whom I am desperately in Love. You saw both the parties last night in the Temple-garden.

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: They seem both of much worth.— But well, Sir, you have, I suppose, discover'd to her de ver great Affecshoon vid which your heart does boil over, and all that?

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: And, She takes it to the death?

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Not so: Nor much to the life. I am in the middle Class of Lovers.

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: So much the better; Extreams are dangerous.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: But, to observe the method of Romances, now you have had my Adventure, pray let's know yours.

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: You shall. But first— hem.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: Nothing, nothing.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: More tricks still? who's this?

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: One, out of whose company I never venture my self, as much a man as I am.— You need not be so strange, Brother, 'tis my Maid.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Old Acquaintance! how dost thou? Let's kiss a little. How do thy Breeches fit thee? Ha, Wench!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Out upon ye, Mr. Goodfeild, you are the strangest man; will ye never leave your old tricks?

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Now, Sister, your story.

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: 'Tis briefly this: My Mother (like a very dutiful Mother i'the mean time) has lately concluded, without my consent or knowledge, to marry me to Sir Alexander Simple. (you know the fool.) And now she's come up to perfect the Match here, as to the Law-part—

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: All this I know already.

sp.speaker: B. Good.
