sp.p: That breeds my wonder.— But to proceed: You may well suppose I abhor'd to marry such a Coxcomb: 'twas therefore by my Maid's advice, here, I resolved to follow the old woman, Incognito; I performed it, and by good fortune have got Lodgings neer hers: Here I have means to observe her progress in this Affair, and take all opportunities to interrupt it. And before I left the Country, I resolved, if I found the business desperate on my part, I would never see her again, nor leave London. Then in few days I had acquainted you at Cambridge, where I was, and the occasion, and submitted my self to your conduct.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Well said, my Girl! thou shall loose nothing by my conduct, unless it be thy Maidenhead, to a good Husband.— Have not you appointed another Duel this morning?

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: Something of that nature. Your friend that I saw with you last night, appeared so much a Gentleman, and I liked his presence so well, I cou'd not forbear quarrelling with him; or if you had rather have it Stilo recitativo— E're since his bright Eyes, my heart did surprize, I cou'd not extinguish the flame.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Nay, nay, your Champion expects you yonder at the place appointed; and let me tell ye, you cannot be more taken with his person, than he is with your Wit and Raillery. But when he knows you are my Sister, he'll be o're head and ears in Love, for he has often heard me speak of ye, and received your Character with much pleasure.— Well; you and I have met this morning to fight, and parted without breathing a vein, or so; but in all probability your second Duel will have a more bloudy conclusion than the first.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Madam, Madam, fear nothing; your Brother talks thus only to fright ye.

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: Fright me? that's a good one, e'faith! no, Frank, I am more a woman than to fear any thing of that nature.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Well, a propos; to loose no more time, and keep neither of ye any longer in suspence, shall I conduct ye to him?

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: Stay— were it not better, and more to the honour of our Sex, for you to fetch him hither?

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Away, away; are you a man, and stand upon such Effeminate Punctilio's? You see he has met you half way; and you cannot in honour, but observe the appointed place of Combat.

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: So, in effect, the Challenge will prove no better than an Assignation.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: No matter: 'tis the pleasanter Encounter; and that sort of single Combat has less of danger in it.

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: As it may happen, Brother.— But let that pass. A Sudden thought is sprung within my breast (as the new Play has it)— you say he fancies me extreamly, as I am a Boy?

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: And withal, he has a very great love for my Name, as I am your Sister in Darbyshire: I mean, Love by hear-say.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: 'Tis very true.—

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: Enough. Come along; we'll to him immediately: But observe that you do and say exactly what I tell ye, as we go.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Well! thou art so full o'thy Tricks!

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Methinks my little Monsieur makes me wait too long: I am almost a weary with walking for him. Hum. Susppose he has fought Ned Goodfeild in earnest, and so the Constables have apprehended them in the Fact, and thereupon conveyed'em both to a certain place.— Yet it cannot be so, I'm confident; that little fellow cannot be a Fighter— and yet what a Devil makes him so tedious? they might have dispatcht it one way or other before this time. I long to see my young opposite; 'tis a very witty Rogue; and I know the Duel will prove but a Wit combat at most— But these delays are naught for Wit, as well as Love and Fighting— Pox on't, the humour's gone over before we draw our Weapons.— Well, l'll take t'other Turn, and then—

div.stage: Enter Goodfeild, B. Goodfeild, and Frank.

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: Look where he walks yonder, as dull as a Platonick Lover: Is it the thought of Fighting makes him thus pensive?

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: No, I assure you: he's none of those.— Iack Truman.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: (turning) Oh, Ned! art thou alive still?— What! my little Bully too? Now I perceive thou art a Boy of thy word. I thought thou would'st ha'proved Recreant.

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: Who, I fall back from my own Challenge? Gad, Sir, you have nothing about ye, that I'm afraid of.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Hark ye, Iack; a word in private.— D'you observe this little Raskal?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Aye, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Little do you think what was his Affair with me this morning— he had no designe of fighting.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Why, I always thought so.— He a fighter? who a Devil can fancie, that Smock-face to look like a Hector?

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: In brief, Iack, he is a young fellow of a good Estate in our Country; I have often heard of him, but never saw him till now: When he challenged me yesterday, 'twas only to procure a more private opportunity of discourse; and now he tells me, he is much a Servant to my Sister, and loves her to the last point: my Mother knows nothing, but he has made several addresses to her, and finds she is wholly at my disposal, and will never fancie any one, but who I commend: And now he comes to open himself to me, and get my good will, as they say.—

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: He seems moved at this. I warrant him a thorough-paced-Lover.

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: This is the way to trie him, Wench.—

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: And so; you have consented?

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: What a question is there! Have not I engaged my self to thee?— Thou hast obliged me with a Mistriss, Iack Truman; and e'faith I'll fit thy humour with an other.— As for the Squire there—

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Damn him; does he come hither to disturb my Amours?— Hark ye, Country-Gentleman.

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: ‛ Say ye, Sir?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Nay, nay, leave your Grimace, and be serious: I am not disposed to railly.— I understand you pretend to a young Lady in the Country that is my Mistriss. Look ye, Mister— you must quit your claim to her, and that quickly too, or I shall give your little Worship much Correction; d'you minde me? much Correction: for I hate a Rival, and love her extreamly.

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: And never saw her in your life? I perceive you are a good Catholick lover, and have a strong implicit faith. It were a happy time for crooked Virgins, and the like, if all Matches might be made thus, without Demonstration.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: These are but idle words: Come, Sir, to the matter. Will ye surrender your Mistriss?

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p:
How, Sir, surrender? Morblew! d'you talk of surrendring,
when I come here to bid you battail?— Look ye, Sir, there's Mr. Goodfeild on your side, if he please, and I have here my friend to oppose him; so that we are provided of Seconds: But I confess I had rather fight ye single.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Aye, aye, let it be so.— But I cou'd wish—

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: That I wou'd surrender without fighting—

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: No: that thou wert more a man, and then I need not blush at such a little Conquest.

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: For my part, I'll be ingenious. I confess I have been a servant to your Mistriss; and to tell ye true, I have been very familiar with her: therefore, look ye, I care not two pins if I do quit her to ye, for once; but I must tell ye, you'll have no such Prize of her. She's damnably Crooked, and all that: then she paints like the Devil: she has a Mouth like a Monster: and is blinde of one Eye: her Nose, I confess, is a rich one; but (to be brief) she has the poorest Presence that e're ye saw in a woman. Then for her Wit and Genius, 'tis as defective as her Beauty.— With such a Match as this is, give ye Joy, Sir.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Why, this is not to be endured! I'd rather he had continued still to be my Rival, than thus blaspheme my Mistriss.— Come, Sir, draw—

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Hold, Iack; be thine own Judge whether she lies, or no.

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: Nay, nay, let him run his Mistriss through, and see who'll repent it.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Mock me not, friend: can I be so happy to find a Mistriss in a Rival?— Oh, Madam!

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: Where was now your good Genius to prompt ye? (as you know who says)— Perhaps you'll say my Brother plaid that part.— Come, put up, put up your Weapon, Sir; you are a little too forward: 'tis not the Mode to quarrel 'till after Marriage.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Well, Madam, by this fair hand— (Takes her hand & kisses it. I vow, I can never forgive the injurie you have done your self and truth, in such a Character: and I am resolved, e're long, to be revenged on ye for it, to some purpose.

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: No threatnings, I beseech you, Sir. Your great Threatners are ever the least performers.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Are you not much surprised, Iack, at this discovery?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Extreamly; but more pleased.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Nay, I my self was as great a stranger to the Intrigue, till this morning.— Come, you shall know all, as we go.

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: Aye, aye, let's return: Now my Duels are over, I have no more occasion for the open field.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: True, Sister: A private apartment is much more proper for what's like to follow.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: But as we walk, Madam, how are you pleas'd I shall treat ye in this disguize? as a Mistriss, or a friend?

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: As a friend, Sir, for life. If you appear too servile while I am in Breeches, you will incourage me to wear 'em always.—

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Here's my boy— Honnow, Sirrah, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Sir, this Letter was brought to your Chamber this morning. I have been in quest of ye at several places, and at last imagined you might be here a walking.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Look here, Ned Goodfeild, this comes to me from Spruce, Docket's Clerk; no doubt it contains intelligence of your Mistriss— read it.

body.p: Sir, my Master, the Venerable Attorney Mr. Docket, sallies forth this morning to one Madam Goodfeild, a rich Country-Widow, I mean a Wooing, or perhaps something more; for if I can apprehend any thing from what I hear, 'tis possible it may succeed. He began with her last night in no ill hour, and (according to a Widows expedition in these affairs) he may meet with his match this morning.— But this is not the business of my Letter. If you have any affairs with Mistriss Lucia, you may use your discretion. Be at your Chamber, and within these few hours you shall receive further assistance from

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: Frank, dost thou hear? why, this is he that Loveal mention'd at the window.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Assuredly.

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: Then have I obliged a poor Lover, and never knew it. No doubt but I have had a great hand in making this Match.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: How's that?

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: Being minded last night to Gallant my Mother, not dreaming that she had a Servant, I gave her a Song, and the Fiddles, about twelve: to be short, her Maid came to the window, and from her Mistriss told us, she knew we were Mr. Docket's Musick, and very honestly confest he had much engaged her; or words to that purpose.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Gad, ye have done well. Did you but know the nature o'the beast, you wou'd not fancie him for a Father-in-Law, of all men living.

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: Oh! what a Coup d'etourdy have I committed?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: No more of that: 'Tis a very happy accident, and will conduce much to our advantage, for a Reason that I know.— In the mean time, Ned, we must be active: 'Tis a shame that young people shou'd be outstrip'd in their Amours, by two such old Creatures, that have not known what Love is, and the true ends of Marriage, these twenty years. Let's see who shall be married first of all us, and the Devil take the hindmost.— I am for this morning.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: And I.

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: Nay, nay, though the old folks doat, and are hasty, it wou'd not become us to do so. Marriage is a serious thing, and should be thought of. Pray let's look a little before we leap into Wedlock.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: How now, Sister! did not you commit your self to my conduct this morning? Gad, I'll not have my Amours put off one minute for ye, an you were my flesh and bloud a thousand times more than ye are.

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: Nay, be not furious, Brother. Ha, ha, ha, I know what's what as well as all the Brothers in England. For my part, look ye, if it must be so, ye shall finde me civil.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Well, Ned, I'll go now about thy Affair: In the mean time I commit my dear Mistriss to thy charge. As we go, I'll appoint where to meet thee with thine, before the Canonical hour be over.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Come, Sister, now I'm at your service, to wait upon you to your Lodgings, and help to shift ye.

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: Sweet Sir, I have a Maid.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Then I'll shift her.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: That you sha'nt I assure you, Sir; for to shift a Maid, is to make her a woman.

div.head: SCENE II.
A Dressing-Chamber.
div.stage: A Table, with a Glass and Boxes, &c.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Loveal, what's a clock?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: 'Tis neer Eight, Madam.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Come, dress me quickly; for I'm resolved to make a day on't. I protest, Mr. Docket's Musick run in my head all night.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: They call it Serenading here in London, as the people of the house tell me: Without doubt it was a signe of great kindness to your Ladyship. Well; I vow, Madam, I dreamt of him to night, and me thought he was such a fine man; and performed things so well.— Oh, Iupiter, that I had but such a Husband, I cou'd be contented to stay a whole half year longer on that condition.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Nay, Wench, I confess he is a well-made man: But methinks I cou'd wish he were a little younger.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: O, Madam, ne're fear that: I warrant he's tough; and though his hair looks now a little grisled, yet one may easily perceive 'twas black; and that's a hardy colour, and holds out well.— But did you observe his Nose, Madam?

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Aye, aye, 'tis a promising Member. But that which likes me best, was to see how loving he appeared in his drink last night: He must needs be good condition'd.— Well, Loveal, how sayst thou, had I best incourage his Wooing, or send him a flat denial? what's thy advice?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Advice, Madam? I hope there needs no advice in the matter: if your own flesh and bloud can't advise ye, you are in a sad condition. For my part, Madam, I'll tell ye true, if I were under your Ladyships Coats, I'd make no more ado but send him a comfortable Message, and marry him this very morning.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Nay, I know there's seldom any good comes of delaying.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I'm sure, Madam, if you had lost so many Suters as I have by that means, and been so often Bob'd as I have been, you'd hate a put-off as you hate the Devil.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p:
Well said, Wench; nay, nay, I am not much averse to the business: I only felt you a little, how you were inclined; and since
I finde you are of my opinion, I perceive two heads are better than one.— Prethee, Loveal, call the Boy.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: (going to the door)— Iack— he's a coming, Madam.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Come hither, Sirrah. Can you go to Mr. Dockets? and come again presently; and not play at Chuck-farthing by the way?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Yes forsooth, Madam.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Yet it's no matter, neither.— Is Trupenny about the house?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Yes, Madam.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Go, send him to me quickly.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Yes, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I vow, Madam, our Boy is become very mannerly of late.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Aye, aye, Wench; I hope to get credit by him: and your proud Citizens Wives shall see that we in the Country can tell how to breed other peoples children, too, if we are minded.— But here comes Trupenny. Enter Trupenny. Come hither, Steven. What, you went home with Mr. Docket last night?

sp.speaker: Trup.
sp.p: Yes, Madam: And I protest, he kept me with him above an hour, to toss your Ladyships Health over and over in a quart of Mum.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Well, Steven, in my minde your Mum is not comparable to our Darbyshire-Ale: it has a good Body, indeed, but is nothing so palletable.

sp.speaker: Trup.
sp.p: Kuds niggers, Madam, you say true: it tasts so strong of Beans, o'my conscience they Mault Beans in that Country where they make it, and so put in a double quantity of Hops, and that's all.

sp.speaker: Good,
sp.p: Nay, nay, I believe I cou'd tell how to brew Mum, an I had a minde.— But let that pass: Come hither, Steven, and minde what I say. I wou'd have ye go presently to Mr. Dockets— d'you observe?

sp.speaker: Trup.
sp.p: Yes, Madam.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Well: tell him, I sent you to see how he does this morning— wou'd not that be best, Loveal?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: No, Madam, I think 'twou'd be better thus— tell him, my Lady and I— d'you observe me, Steven?— present our Service to him, and wou'd desire him of all Love—

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Aw, Loveal, I doubt that wou'd not be handsome, neither. Therefore, d'you minde me, Steven? only tell him this, I wou'd have him make haste, and put on a clean Band, and—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Oh, Madam, never talk of a clean Band; he'll wear a Cravat to day, sure, though he ne're wore one in his life before. Look ye, Steven, minde me; Tell him thus; First of all knock at the door, and ask if he be within, then ask if he be stirring; then he'll send for you up to his Bed-side— I protest, Madam, I think ye had better let me go, foro'my Conscience, he'll ne're do the business handsomely.

sp.speaker: Trup.
sp.p: I war'nt ye, Madam.— Lord, Mrs. Loveal, d'you think your self such a woman for the business? I hold a Crown, I do it as well as you can for your heart and bloud, or your Mother before ye.—

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Well, good Steven, no more words, but make haste; and tell him only this, I wou'd have him come and speak with me presently, and I shall satisfie him in the business which he mention'd last night. This is all at present, but run, good Steven, for fear he be gone out.

sp.speaker: Trup.
sp.p: I shall, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Hark ye, Steven, tell him, my Lady desires he wou'd bring his man with him that was here last night.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: He don't hear.— But 'tis no matter; leave that to me; I'll provide thee a Husband, I warrant thee, Wench.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Aye, Madam, you have often said so; but words are wind, and I want something that's more substantial.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Nay, if I say I will, I will; though it cost me a hundred pound.— Come, put on my shoos.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I'll fetch'em, Madam; they are in the next Room.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: No matter: I'll go thither my self, and take one Pipe, and by that time, perhaps, the party will be come.

div.head: SCENE III.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Sir, what are you pleas'd shall be done in Mr. Richman's business? the Sheriff of Essex has return'd nulla Bona on the sifa; and to take out a Casa, would be to little purpose; for I am told, the Defendant can't be found in rerum naturum, and some say he's gone to Sea.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: No matter; let that rest. The Plaintiff han't fee'd me for Expedition this Term.— But have you delivered the Declarations in Ejectment yet?

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: What, those in Holborn, Sir?

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: Yes, in Com. Middlesex.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: No, I protest, Sir, not yet.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: O fie, Thomas, don't you know the Tenants in Possession are to appear and defend Crastino Trin? and you no forwarder?— Away, man, and about it presently; and as ye go, take the Devonshire Latitats, and seal 'em. But d'you hear, Thomas, be sure ye return within this hour, for I intend then to go forth; and we must not be both out.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: It shall be done, Sir.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: This Dashwel, is a rare fellow for business: I protest, I have had many Clerks, but never had the like. Spruce, come hither: Do you observe the Tallents of your fellow Dashwel?

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Yes, Sir; they are something long. He cuts his Nails but once a fortnight, and then observes the Moon precisely.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: Ye Fool; I mean his gifts, and Qualifications.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Cry ye mercie, Sir, I understand ye now. Indeed, Sir, he writes an excellent Hand; but his Court is beyond comparison.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p:
That's not all, Spruce, that's not all: He's one that loves the Law, nay, doats upon the Law; I mean, the Practick part: and o'my conscience he was cut out for a Practiser in his Mothers belly. He's one that has found out the amorous Beauties, and the ravishing Graces of Practice; things that none can perceive, but such a one as he is. In comparison to these, he hates your Plays, your Masquerades, your Serenades, your Revellings (except only at Christmas, and then the good Soul is ravisht in the Temple-hall
where he drinks small Beer, and sees'em dance till his belly akes agen) but above all things, he abhors, like a childe of the Law, your damn'd Poetry; with which, Spruce, I fear you are a little infected.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Who I, Sir? God forbid. I vow, I have so great an aversion to Meeter, and all that, that if you'll believe me, I dare not sing Psalms for fear o'the worst.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: Nay, Spruce, there you are again a t'other side: I wou'd not have ye think there's any harm in Robert Wiseman's Psalms, nor in the old Song of Chevie Chace, but that they may be both used, and very innocently. And more than so, I believe there are some Volumes of Meeter that are very convenient, and of great use in a Lawyer's Study, as The Garland of Good will, The furious fight of Floddon-field, and all Mr. Wither's his Works; all these I believe Dashwel has, and need not be ashamed of 'em. Nay, I can very well remember, when I first learnt Court-hand I had all the Ballat of the Two little Children by heart, and me thought it was so comfortable. But that which ought to be odious to the understanding of all true Clerks, is your modern Poetry, your new fashion or modish Poetry, your Play-Poetry, or Dramatick Meeter, your ranting and tearing Poetry, your Poetry that breaks windows, or, as they themselves call it, your Heroick Poetry.— (Knocking without. Spruce, see who's at door.

div.stage: Spruce goes to the door, and enters with Trupenny.

sp.speaker: Spruce.
sp.p: (entering) Sir, here's Mr. Trupenny, with urgent business from his Lady.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: Oh, Sweet Mr. Trupenny! Let me embrace my dear friend: And how does thy good Lady, ha? I protest, Mr. Trupenny, I was resolved to wait upon her within this half hour, to know her resolutions in the business aforesaid: You understand me?

sp.speaker: Trup.
sp.p: Lord, Sir! how you and my Lady jump together. Let me never stir now, if she has not sent me to you for the very same end and purpose; namely, that ye shou'd hye ye to her, and she'd give your Worship all the satisfaction imaginable.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: Say'st thou so, old boy? hold, here's six Fees I protest, a whole Guiny for thy good news: Ten groats is below such a Message— Spruce, here, take my Hat, run, fetch my new Beaver, my Cane and my Gloves, quickly: I'll not demur a minute. Oh, Sweet Mr. Trupenny!

sp.speaker: Trup.
sp.p: I vow to God, Sir, you are such an obliging man.— Pray, Sir, have ye done any thing in Mrs. Betty's business? I make bold to ask, because my Lady has ordered me to slit that cause, as they say.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: Not yet, Sir; I protest, I have been so busie: But it shall be dispatcht in good time.

sp.speaker: Trup.
sp.p: Nay, nay, let it rest: 'tis fit the old one should be served first.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Sir, here are your things.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: Well said: Give 'em me. So; now, Mr. Trupenny, I am ready to wait upon ye. Come, Sir—

sp.speaker: Trup.
sp.p: After you, Sir—

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: Lord, Mr. Trupenny, you are so Complemental! I vow, you shall go first—

sp.speaker: Trup.
sp.p: Well, if it must be so—

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: O Lord, what had I forgot! Now if my life lay on't I cannot go till Dashwel returns.

sp.speaker: Trup.
sp.p: I hope not so, Mr. Docket. God knows what occasion my Lady has of ye.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: Ah, Mr. Trupenny, ye say true; and I wou'd go with all my heart; but if you did but know what occasion I have to stay at home at this time, you wou'd not blame me— Hark ye, Sir, a word in private. You must know, Mr. Trupenny, I have here in the house a very pretty young Niece, a great fortune she is: her Father and Mother are both dead, but that's all one, for I am her Guardian.

sp.speaker: Trup.
sp.p: How's this? a pretty woman i'the house, and I ne're set eye on her as oft as I have been here? Time has been, that I have smelt out a pretty Wench at a streets length: it's a signe I grow old.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: Nay, never wonder, Mr. Trupenny: She always keeps her Chamber, or to say true, I keep her there. For I protest, here are so many idle fellows about the Town, that I dare not let her be seen, as little as possibly. And besides that, I have a constant eye upon her my self; but in my absence, I commit that trust generally to Dashwel. As for this Spruce, he's a slie fellow, and I dare not leave her to him.

sp.speaker: Trup.
sp.p: What, you are afraid they wou'd be nought together while you are out? not unlikely.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: No; but he's a cunning Raskal in these affairs: and who knows but he may let her out to some young fellow, or else help some young fellow in to her? Therefore I dare not trust him; and yet I wou'd sain go to your Lady.—

sp.speaker: Trup.
sp.p: What an unluckie thing is this! Is there no way?—

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: O Lord, Mr. Trupenny, now I think on't— are you engaged in any urgent business, at this time?

sp.speaker: Trup.
sp.p: All my business was only to you, Sir, with this Message— But since you can't come, I must return, and let my Lady know it.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: No, no, that sha'nt be. I'll go my self: But in the mean time, sweet Mr. Trupenny, let me conjure you, as you are my friend, and the like, to stay behind and supply my place, as it were. You understand me? 'Tis but only till Dashwel comes, which will be within this half hour.

sp.speaker: Trup.
sp.p: Nay, nay, if that be all, let me alone to watch her water; I'm old dog at that office. I dare swear, I have occupied the place above twenty times in the Country.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: O, Sir, how you oblige me? Well, I'll leave ye. Say nothing, but fall into discourse with Spruce, and all's, well. I have tarri'd too long from your Lady, I confess, but I'll redeem the time, and run all the way.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: What, is he gone, and does this fellow stay? O the Devil! (aside) now cannot I perform to Mr. Truman; and then I've lost my Credit for ever. Some trick must be thought of.— Dear Sir, how glad am I my Master has left us together? I have often wisht this happy opportunity, to be better acquainted with good Mr. Trupenny. I vow, Sir, you are the goodest Gentleman I ever met with.

sp.speaker: Trup.
sp.p: O, Sir, your humble Servant. No great Gentleman neither: My Father was a High-constable, and I am my Lady's Steward, in default of a better— But I pray, Mr. Spruce, if a man may be so bold— what a clock is't?

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Not bolder than welcome, I assure ye, Sir. Why truly, Sir, I think 'tis betwixt nine and ten.

sp.speaker: Trup.
sp.p: Aye, Sir; but I meant to have craved a glass of your small Beer, but I protest I was almost ashamed.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir, it's none of the best, being very thin, and something sowr: and (as you say verie well) it's a shame to drink it.

sp.speaker: Trup.
sp.p: Not so neither, Sir; I do not mean so, Sir; but I vow to Gad, Sir, your Master pli'd me so with Mum last night, that I'm as dry this morning, as a Post horse; and my stomach is a little— as it were.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Shall we go to the next Apothecaries, and drink a Gill of Stomach-water?

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: No, Sir, no, that needs not; my Lady has an excellent water in the Country that she makes her self: but that's nothing, you'll say, we are here, and that's there.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: When all's done, I say, after a nights drinking, there's no settler like a Dose of the same next morning. Come, Sir, you shall go with me to a place hard by, where there's excellent Mum; faith, we'll have one pint together. Nay, it sha'nt cost ye a farthing.

sp.speaker: Trup.
sp.p: (aside) Now wou'd this cunning Rogue whedle me from my charge: but soft, old birds are not caught with chaff.— I tell ye, Sir, I do not love Mum; it has no pleasurable taste: therefore if you please, I'll take a seat.— Hark, what Musick's this?

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: (aside) A pox on him for me; now shall I never be rid of him.— Musick? what Musick?

sp.speaker: Trup.
sp.p: Why don't ye hear, man?

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Oh, cry ye mercie; I hear it now: 'Tis a young Lady of my acquaintance that wou'd be private.

sp.speaker: Trup.
sp.p: Nay, nay, I w'ont disturb her.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: To tell ye true, 'tis my Masters Niece, whom he has, for faults best known to himself, confin'd to her Chamber. I perceive she is preparing for a Song; and then you'll hear the best Voice in London, Mr. Trupenny.

sp.speaker: Trup.
sp.p: Aye marry Sir, I love singing with all my heart; and time was, when I cou'd a—

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Whist, whist.

lg.l: Ah! how charming is the shade,
How sweet the calm delight,
That in this amorous Grove is made;
How cool the shade, and yet the day how bright!
Hark! the little Philomel
On yonder Bough complains,
And while she her sad tale does tell,
Eccho replies in the same mournful strains.
Thus, thus, is both the eye and ear
Ravisht with what they see and hear.
Does not all this
Invite us to soft Love, and mutual Bliss?
See my Clymene, see,
How that enamour'd pair of Doves
With melting Sympathy,
Enjoy their ever equal Loves.
They know no eares, nor feel they ought
To trouble the more pleasing thought.
Full of the same
Soft fire they burn, and cherish the kinde flame.
Ah! happy, happy they!
We two may full as happy be,
If you but smile, and say,
Content, Amintas, I agree.
Content, Amintas, I agree.

sp.speaker: Trup.
sp.p: By that sigh, with which the Lady concludes her Song, I presume, Mr. Spruce, she is in Love.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Truly, Mr. Trupenny, it is not impossible; for our Ladies here in London are apt, once in their lives at least, to love something or other: what they do in the Country I know not.— But a fig for your women, and all that belongs to 'em: Let us behave our selves like men. Methinks it is the unseemliest thing in the world for us two to sit here like sots, when we have so excellent an opportunity for a Voyage to the next Tavern or Ale-house, and taste a merry Glass.

sp.speaker: Trup.
sp.p: (aside) O'ho, are ye there? He's at it again to drill me off, but all this w'ont do.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: I perceive ye are all very sober men, in your Country.

sp.speaker: Trup.
sp.p: Nay, nay, no more Sobrietie than will do us good; but that's all one. Look ye, Mr. Spruce, for your Wine I don't love it, and for your Ale, ye have not a drop in London worth drinking; that's the short on't.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: How, Mr. Trupenny, not a drop worth drinking? Did you ever taste our Cock-ale?

sp.speaker: Trup.
sp.p: Cock-ale, no; what's that?

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Why, there you shew your ignorance. Look ye, Sir, I lay ye five pound you shall say, ye never tasted the like in the Country.

sp.speaker: Trup.
sp.p: Nay, nay, nay, nay, five pound is a wager not to be laid among friends; and besides that, I have not so much about me; but I hold a Crown, let it be what it will, we have Ale in Darbyshire worth ten on't.—

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Ye make me mad. I hold an Angel to your Crown, that after the first Bottle, you your self shall confess, that for Colour, Taste, Farewel, Body, and all that, it excels your Darbyshire, as far as your Darbyshire excels your Dashwood.

sp.speaker: Trup.
sp.p: How, I confess it? Sir, here's the Guiny your Master gave me e'en now, I wager this to your Angel, I'll be hang'd first. Come, lead away; this wager shall be tried presently.— I'll stand up for my Country while I breathe.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: But perhaps you are otherwaies engaged at present; or perhaps you have made a vow not to he seen in an Ale-house.

sp.speaker: Trup.
sp.p: No matter for that, Sir, I'll not suffer my Country to be run down, by ne're a pittiful Londoner in England. Come along, Sir.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Nay, then prepare to say, we've better drink.

sp.speaker: Trup.
sp.p: Which if I do, I'll hang; that's fair I think.

div.head: SCENE I.
Fleet-street.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: WEll, now I have brought ye together, ye know best your own Affairs, and how to husband time with most advantage. I must return to my Steward, that was so lately, Madam, your trusty Overlooker.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Prethee, what hast thou done with him?

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Why, faith, Sir, after I had drawn him from his Post, by the means I told ye, I very soberly conveyed my Gentleman to the Cock-ale-house, where in conclusion he will be very drunk: for, as good luck wou'd have it, I was no sooner enter'd, but I met there a certain true Trojan (indeed a Brother Clerk of my acquaintance) I left him, after a charming glass or two gone round—

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: But missing you, may he not make an escape, suspecting—

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: His Companion's more trusty Keeper. No, Sir, no, he's as fast as if he were in the Stocks for three lives; I mean, for parting Compos mentis. If he have not a better opinion of London-Liquor ever after, let 'em spare their Cocks, and boyl me in the next Brewing: And that shall be call'd Spruce-ale— Oh, how your City-wives will flock to't!

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Sir, your Coach is ready, and waits where you appointed:

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Enough. Come, Madam, give me the honour to conduct you to your Servant; whom when you have known but half as well as I do, you will confess to be the worthiest Lover, as I the best of Friends.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: You see, Sir, what a confidence I give to what you tell me, and how I trust your Conduct. I must confess, with many Blushes, I have no Aversion to his love or person: But still I tremble when I think my Uncle (whose severe nature I too well know) may dash my happiness with many sorrows.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Think not of that, dear Madam, Fortune is more indulgent. Your Uncle is this morning with my Friend's Mother, a rich Widdow, in the heighth of his Wooing: And you may easily conclude, Madam, he dares not shew displeasure at her Sons Match, since so advantageous, for that's the way to disoblige his Mistriss.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Then, Sir, why may not he know it beforehand?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: By no means. If so, he will undoubtedly by some sinister means prevent it, and that purely for lucre of your Portion, Madam: But when 'tis done, he cannot disapprove it, for the former Reason. Besides, an opportunity or advantage once neglected, is in Love, as in a Battail, never to be recover'd.—

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Oh, Madam! we are all defeated: Yonder comes Dashwel, your old spy; if he sees us here, or finds us not at home, he'll raise the Hue and Crie, and we are lost for ever.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Fear nothing; but you three cross over there, and away: Leave me to him, and if I don't prevent his doing mischief, think me a duller sot than he is.

div.stage: Enter Dashwel at one door, and at the other Exeunt Truman, Lucia, Maid.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Oh! you are a rare one, to stay thus long.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: I cou'd not help it for my heart and bloud, I vow now. A Country-man, an old acquaintance, met me in Holborn, and wou'd needs give me a Pint.— But is my Master gone out?

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Then omnia bene. I'll make haste to him, for I know he sits upon thorns.—

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Hold. You must not go in: there's Madam Goodfeild with him, and they are private. But shou'd you know all, you'd cut your throat, that's certain, for being out o'the way.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: What, Felo de se? I'll be hang'd first.— But prethee, good Spruce, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: O'my Conscience, you deal with the Devil, or else you were wrapt in your Mothers Smock; one o'the two, I'm confident. Come, come, I know you make use of Philters, Amulets, and Love-potions, or something of that nature.—

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: If I do, the Dews take me. You know there's the Statute of Primo against it.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Aye, aye, but that's nothing: for here was Mrs. Loveal came with her Lady; but now she's gone.—

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Ah, what a Rogue was I to be away.— Ah, sweet Mrs. Loveal! and how much she made of me last night!

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Look ye; I knew you wou'd run mad at this, and never hear me out.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I will hear thee: Dear Spruce, say on.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: With Mrs. Loveal came a delicate young thing about Eighteen, whom she call'd Couzin; but I vow, she was the finest woman, I e're saw in my life—

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Oh!—

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Such a pretty Mouth, and such a little plump Lip,—

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Oh!—

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: A little nimble Hand and Foot; and then withal so slender, you might span her.—

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Oh!—

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Round amorous Breasts, that heave and pant with Love: white and soft as Down of Swans—

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Oh!—

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Then to crown all, an Eye like any Basilick— you know, Tom, a Basilick has a delicate Eye.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Aye, aye,— Oh! that I had been at home. Oh! that cursed Country-man, and that damn'd Tavern.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Mrs. Loveal had not been entered so long as you might tell one hundred, but that she askt me for ye— and smil'd like any thing.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Did she e'faith? I vow, I am beholding to her.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: I told her you were abroad. At this she seem'd as sad as if she'd had her purse cut.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Alack, alack, Poor heart!

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: After this she staid but little; and parting, with a low Curtesie, desired me to remember her Love to ye, and tell ye, she and her Couzin were going directly to the Folly, where they shou'd both be very glad to see ye.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Edad, I'll go put on a clean pair of Sleeves, and follow 'em immediately.—

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Ye ben't mad? If ye loose time ye loose 'em. They are hardly got to the' Temple-stairs yet: Away directly, 'tis ten to one you overtake 'em.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Ye say true; farewel. If my Master ask for me, make some Lye or other, and all's well.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Let me alone for lying— But d'you hear? She bid me tell you, that if you find 'em not at the Folly, you will not fail to have 'em in the long Walk at the New-spring-garden.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Enough—

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: One word more.— But, saies she, If we shou'd chance to be gone from thence, he will be sure to meet me at my Couzins Lodgings—

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Dear Spruce, where's that?

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: At the signe of the Windmil in the Old-pell-mell.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Enough, enough; I'll not delay my joys one minute longer.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: So; thou art secure for one three hours. This Dashwel is the easiest Gudgion! he gulps a Lye as readily as Juglers swallow Knives. Now to my Steward; if he has swallow'd Glasses with equal haste and pleasure, he's in his altitudes by this time.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: Enter Ned Goodfeild, B. Goodfeild, and Frank, in their own Apparel.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: NOW I can call you Sister again, with a safe Conscience. Methinks, before ye lookt like a Brother of the Blade, or a kinde of little Huff.— Come, bear up, the Rendezvous is not far off.

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: Methinks you are grown very Heroick, Brother? you think of nothing but close fighting. For my part, since I am return'd to Petticoats again, my minde is not so masculine as lately. And I consider, more distance wou'd more become this Habit.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Cunning Hypocrite! Now shou'd not I proceed in this Assignation, you your self wou'd be my chief Tormentor; and my own flesh and bloud, like another Brutus, wou'd give me the first Bodkin.—

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: As sure as can be.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Fie, fie, Sister, be more ingenious: This backward dissimulation of a longing Female, is odious in a Person of Quality, and a Town-Lady, and shews the coursest breeding in the world. I shall be asham'd to keep you company, unless you converse with more Integrity and Candour.

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: Faith, Brother, I can't help it. Since I shifted my Apparel, I am infected with what belongs to a Petticoat and Wastecoat: 'tis the humour of the Garment, and therefore you must pardon me.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: I do; but Iack Truman shall prescribe your Penance, which if it be more pleasant than the fault deserves, you ought to thank your too indulgent Confessor.

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p:
A propos: Let us make haste then to the place of Exccution.
But by the way, Brother, let me tell you, I think it would be better if—

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: Away with your impertinent Propositions. I think there is nothing in nature so Capricious as a she-wit. Is this a time for advice, when it is now neer eleven a clock, and you know what we are to do effectually before twelve?

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: Yet do but hear my Reasons.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: Well, Madam, since we are agreed on the main point in Issue, and you are pleased once more to lie under Covert-Baron, there's now no more to be done, but to turn down this lane, and we shall quickly arrive at an honest Parson's, my intimate acquaintance, indeed the Ordinary of Newgate, who will give us the Book of Matrimony as compendiously as if he were to teach the Neck-verse.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Soft, Mr. Docket, though we have a Country-proverb, that Marriage and Hanging go by Destiny, yet methinks, for luck-sake, I would not be marri'd by one that deals so neer the Gallows.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: The truth is, Madam, he has often promised to marry me for nothing: but that's all one; rather than displease my dear Widow, I am content to loose his Assumpsit. How like ye, Madam, to be marri'd by a Reader of an Inns a Court? I know 'em all.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: By no means, Sir: Do your Readers at the Inns a Court marry fokes? Never stir, now that's as bad as to be marri'd by a Justice of Peace, out upon't!

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: Nay, my Dear, you mistake me clearly. I mean, a Chappel-Reader.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Cry ye mercie, Mr. Docket, I understand ye now. Well, Sir, what you please.— O my heart! Come hither, Loveal; do ye know those two that stand talking yonder?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: As I hope to live and do well, Madam, I dare say 'tis Mr. Edward Goodfeild, and Mrs. Betty, your Ladyships only Son and Daughter. Nay, I'll be sworn yonder's Frank too.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I vow, I think so. But how come they together, and in London? I left my Daughter in the Country, and sure an God'll my Son's at Cambridge.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I fear me, Madam, there's some naughty designe in hand; for I dare swearupon a Book 'tis they.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: Never trouble your self, Madam, London's a large place, and here's one body or other like every body i'the Nation. For my part; I have sometimes met some-body as I have been going along the street, as like some-body as I know, as e're you saw; and yet when all came to all I have been deceived.

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: Now let me die, and all that, Brother, but yonder's my Mother and her new Servant, a't'other side the way; and as the Devil wou'd have it, she has spi'd us. What shall we do in this case? this is no time to take notice of Mothers.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Well, to be sure, Loveal, we'll walk softly before. Do you step o're the way, and see if it be they for certain, and then follow us.

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: Brother, we are all undone: This wicked Mother of ours has sent her woman over to make further discovery. Look where she comes▪

sp.speaker: Eran.
sp.p: Madam, you spoil all: Be not surprized, but you two stand aside as unconcern'd, and leave me to her; if I don't send her off with less satisfaction than she came on, say I'm not worth your Service.

div.stage: (Good. and B. Good. retire a little.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: (meeting Loveal) Oh! mee cher Maitress, Madam Belamy! Ah, how blessé am I to see mee good Friende a Londres! Merdugues, I am de happy woman in de varlde.

div.stage: Speaking, and Acting like a French woman all this Scene.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: What means this Gibbrish? I understand not a word she says.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Ah, Madame, you cunno I speak no good Englesh. I have been but two day in dis City. Mais Ie Scais bien que vous parlez bon Francois.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Now, for ought I know, she bids the Devil take me, in French. Lord, to see how I was mistaken, to think this was Frank. Well, I'll e'ne back again, and say nothing, lest I appear as much beside the Cushion as she is

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p:
(staying her) Ah, Maistress Belamy, verfore are you so estrange? Ma foy, have you oblie how ver mery we were ensemble last soomer, vid Messieurs de Cour Dauphnie, at de little Caberet, Au teste noir, in de Ru'e St. Jasques a Paris? Look you, Madame, dere stand mee ver good friend Monsieur le Marquis de Montausiere, vid his Sister Madame de Fountain-amante. Give me de honour,
Je vous supply, to introduce you into his cunnisance: you'll finde him de ver noble Gentlemane, and he'll make ver mush of your body, begar.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Pray let me go, Mistriss.— Fie upon her, for a naughty woman! I shall be undone if I stay.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: You need no be affear, sweet Madam Belamy, he was ver well curè a Roan, before he came in Engleterre, begar.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Let me go, I say. I know ye not, not I. And you are mistaken in me, that you are; I am none of those you take me for: my name's Loveal, and not Bellany— How I hate the looks of these French people! It's no wonder we can't abide em. For my part, I never saw any of 'em before, and I hope, never shall again— Let me go, I say.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Ma foy, Madame; mee ask your pardon tres-humblement, if you be not dat good English Lady Maistress Belamy, in whose company I have had the great honour to be garanted a Paris and Fountainbleau. Yet for that you are so ver like the good graces of mee dear friend, if you do please to go along vid Monsieur, Madame, and your Servante, to a little Frigat below de bridge, we have dere one two tree glasses of ver excellent Frontiniack, and de little Collation, to which you will do very great honour, Si vous plaist.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: O Lord, a Spirit, a Spiritd a French Spirit! I shall be carri'd to Barbado's. Away, Spirit, farewel, Sathan; I have heard of your tricks. But soft, older and wiser.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Well▪ how like ye my dispatch?

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: Oh, most cleverly done, Wench! 'Twas a neat Conveyance; there's ne're a Lawyer of 'em in Town can draw a better. Take my best French Point, tomorrow, for thy witty French Wheedle.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: 'Faith 'twas a most important Service, my Girl: and Monsieur the Marquiss de Montausere is your very humble Servant for it. Without doubt, had Loveal been confirmed in her untimely knowledge of us, it wou'd have been no small obstruction to our Designes.

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p:
Yet was the pleasure of the action greater than the profit. I vow, Madam de Fountain-amante had much ado to keep the due Grimace proper to a person of her Quality, and not laugh outright.— But, I'll stay here no longer, Brothers, not only to avoid
such another Rancounter, but chiefly, because I long to be at my Journeys end.

sp.speaker: Good.
sp.p: That is, you think it long to night. I understand ye, Sister.

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: 'Tis well you do: walk you afore, while my Maid ties my shoo-string— I'll follow immediately—

sp.speaker: N. Good.
sp.p: Prethee make haste—

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: So, he is gone (to Frank stooping) away, Wench, let us turn down this lane; I am resolv'd to have one frollick more in the open field of this world, before I enter into the enclosures of Matrimony—

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: 'Slife, Madam, what will your Brother and Servant apprehend from such delays?—

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: No matter for my Brother; as for my Servant, this is my last effort to exercise his patience, and trie how much he loves me— Come away, away—

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: The Scene opens, and discovers Trupenny and Clarke, in play.

sp.speaker: Trup.
sp.p: WEll, all this can't be helpt. But the Devil's in the Cards, that's plain. Uds bud, I've play'd at Put a thousand times, and a thousand to that, but I never had such cursed luck before— Come, Sir, shuffle: But first let's draw the Table more to the light; Gad I have drunk so much, I can scarcely see.

div.stage: They bring the Table forward upon the Stage.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Sha, sha! this is nothing: Give me a man that can sit at it from twelve at noon, to twelve at night, then go to bed sober, and swear there's no strong drink in London: there's your true English heart of Oak.

sp.speaker: Trup.
sp.p: As I live Mr. Clarke, you say finely.— But let us to our Books again—

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Ten such as these would over-run the Low Countries, and drown all Germany in a Rummer. Come, Sir, before we go any further, here's one brimmer to your better fortune. (drinks) Faith, Sir, you have the worst luck of any man living. Loose Eleven games together and never turn Stake? why, you don't drink well, man. Unless you plie the Glass with better Courage, you'll never win a game at One and thirty.

sp.speaker: Trup.
sp.p: Say ye so? Nay, then fill it up; I'll do ye right, e'faith, Boy. If you provoke me once at this Weapon, you'll finde me a mad Boy; I'll tell you that.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Sa, sa. That's he, that's he.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Now, Sir, deal.— (Clark deals. Gad, Sir, I'll see ye. If I loose with these Cards, I'll never play at Put more.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Why then I'm gone. You know, Sir, I'm bound and can't refuse: Play away— that's mine; and there's a Tray, e'faith.

sp.speaker: Trup.
sp.p: That's tied.—

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Gad, there's another Tray, win it and wear it.

sp.speaker: Trup.
sp.p: Uds, I've lost. Was ever such damn'd luck?— Well, I won't leave ye yet— Drawer, bring a fresh pack o'Cards— Come, Sir, I'll double the Stakes; what a Devil, I can't loose alwaies— Let me see— [feels in his pockets]— (aside) Uds bud, I ha' lost all my Money; here's but one poor Nine pence, a Groat and five Farthings— (stamps) Was ever such a cursed hand seen? three Trays at once? What man alive cou'd ha' thought it?— Sir, can you lend me Five shillings?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: How, Sir, lend? Sbud, Sir, you are not in earnest? what butter me with my own money? this is worse than to play upon tick: You must know, Mr. Trupenny, there's a Statute against it; and besides that, it is not the custom of London, I assure ye.

sp.speaker: Trup.
sp.p: No? why then— hark ye, Drawer, a word with ye: thou seemest an honest fellow. (strokes him upon the head) Look ye, Drawer, yon Gentleman has won all my money at Put; prethee lend me half a Crown, to win as much back again as may pay the Reckoning.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Faith, Sir, I can't, and it were to save my life.— By and by, by and by, I come, I come, Sir.

sp.speaker: Trup.
sp.p: Why there's the Devil. Oh, here comes Mr. Spruce: nay; then I care not.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Gentlemen, I must seriously beg your pardon: I have been diverted by so many unluckie accidents, that I protest, my stay has been almost an hour longer than I intended.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: There needs no Apologie, sweet Mr. Spruce; we have been so seriously engaged since you went, that we scarce ever thought o'you.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Well, then I hope you like the Ale, Mr. Trupenny. Come, where stands the Glass? we'll whisk it about, e'faith, boys.

sp.speaker: Trup.
sp.p: Nay, nay, nay, Mr. Spruce, never talk of that. Whisk quoth a? I have had enough of Put, one wou'd think; but that's all one. Hark ye, Mr. Spruce, one word in private: Mr. Spruce, as I hope to live now— yet first I shou'd have told ye— but that's no matter neither— then as I was saying, Sir, your friend yonder has won Thirty shillings of me at half-Crown-put; and nothing vexes me, but he has not left me money enough for another stake. Now, worthy Mr. Spruce, as the saying is, I take you for my friend, and I hope to sinde ye so: Can ye do a man the favour, Sir, as to lend a Crown, or an Angel? As I'm an honest man, you shall ha't again.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: What to do, Mr. Trupenny?

sp.speaker: Trup.
sp.p: Only to win my Thirty shillings back again: nothing else, I protest.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: How, Mr. Trupenny, win it back? I perceive you don't know Mr. Clark: why he's the only Put-man in Town. I hold ye six to four, an ye play with him till midnight, ye shall never win two pence of him. He knows ye all the Cards as well as he that made 'em; and then for the sleek, the nip, the double, and all that, he is the Devil of a Gamster.

sp.speaker: Trup.
sp.p: Nay, Guds sooks, if he be the Devil of a Gamster, I have nothing to say to him. 'Sbud I alwaies thought some such thing.— But now, how shall we do to pass the time? methinks now I'm in, I'm loath to leave good company.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: What think ye of a Wench, Mr. Trupenny? I know a Miss hard by, that is excellent company, Gad: What say ye?

sp.speaker: Trup.
sp.p: Not a word more of that, if you love me, Mr. Spruce. For ought I know, she may be the Devil of a Gamester too. And then, look ye, I had rather loose Thirty shillings at Cards, than give a Surgeon Forty shillings for a cure, and Three pound for seeresie. I must confess, look ye, Mr. Spruce, I love the sport well enough; but pox on't, there's no doing in this noughty Town of London, (as my Lady calls it.) Besides, Sir, shou'd I get it, you understand me; Uds bud, Sir, it were enough to spoil a whole Country.— Come, come, without further ceremony, let us all sit down, and drink while we can stand. Mr. Spruce, my Service to ye.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Sir, your humble Servant—

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: But pray, Mr. Trupenny, why are you such an enemy to London?

sp.speaker: Trup.
sp.p: Fough, I hate it.— Why, did you never hear the Song?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: The Song, what Song?

sp.speaker: Trup.
sp.p: Why this 'tis to be an ignorant Londoner.— I'll tell ye, Mr. Spruce, for you are my friend, and an understanding person. It was made by a very honest fellow in our Country that chanc'd to be at Bartholomew-fair once, and had his pocket pickt.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Aye, aye, I knew him very well; his name was Bartholomew Cokes.

sp.speaker: Trup.
sp.p: No, Sir, he was none of your Cokes, I assure ye, but a Kinsman of mine at Mansfield. To see how your'e mistaken with your Cokes ' s.—

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Nay, nay, never minde him, man, but on with your Song.

sp.speaker: Trup.
sp.p: Cuds bud, it's the finest Song you e're heard in your life. The Clerk of our Parish sings it rarely to the tune of the Sixteenth Psalm, and it will go to Green sleeves, but that's all one— I'll sing it as well as I can.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Aye, sweet Mr. Trupenny, let's ha't.

sp.speaker: Trup.
sp.p: Hem, hem.— Faith, Gentlemen, my voice is but so, so. But that's no matter. Time was when I cou'd have done well; but—

div.stage: To be sung al▪ yvronge, in a drunken humour.

lg.l: O London, wicked London-Town!
Whose Spots so many and so brown,
Deform thy face in such a fashion,
Thou dost appear the one black Patch—
Yea, of the Nation.
Ye Ladies that wear powder'd Toors:
Ye honest Women eek, and Whores,
Reform your lives, and by degrees
Leave the Back-fall, and rather fall—
Yea, on your knees.
Ye Gallants that wear Sword and Scabbard;
Ye Coopers eek, that deal in Clapboard,
Repent for shame: and do ye hear?
Drink no more Sack, but rather Ale—
Yea, drink small Beer.
Ye men of Trade that deal in Lying,
I mean, in Selling and in Buying,
Look to your Wives, for it is spoken,
They are as crackt as you your selves—
Yea, full as broken—

div.p: Boy, bring another Chamber-pot. Plague on ye, you Rogue, you never empty.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Didst thou ever hear a foolish Song worse sung in thy life, Dick Clark?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: 'Tis beyond expectation ridiculous.— But hang him; this Country-Fop begins to be cursed drunk, and his humour will quickly become tedious: Let's dispatch him, and away.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Withal my heart. T'other Glass does the work.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Or else the Devil's in him. Let me die, I am consident the Sot has drunk at least Eight or ten bottles for his own share in less than an hour. While he was busie in play, I us'd to fill the Glass and set it by him, and he wou'd never minde, but take off Three or Four together in that manner. As for example, you shall see— (Clark fills and sets it to Trupenny. Methinks you droop, Mr. Trupenny?

sp.speaker: Trup.
sp.p: No, Sir, not droop; there's nothing of drooping in the case, I assure you; but only I was thinking of a thing which I had quite forgot; that is, Mr. Spruce, how I shou'd have staid at your Master's Chamber, about a thing that I know— But hang't let it pass, here's a Health in a Rummer.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p:
I protest, Mr. Trupenny, you are the merriest man— Ha, ha, he— But all this while I must not forget to be civil. Look you, Mr. Trupenny, here's one Glass I'll put about to your best Concern;
I mean, the good health of your good Lady Madam Goodfeild— Mr. Clark, my Service to you.

sp.speaker: Trup.
sp.p: Hold, Sir— you shall excuse me, efeckins.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: What, not your Ladies health?

sp.speaker: Trup.
sp.p: Not so, Sir; I do not mean so, Sir, I assure you: But only I'll begin it my self— well, I say nothing; but she's as good a Lady as any in England, and has as able a Servant as any in the world— but that's all one. I defie your pimping Glasses (throws away the Glass.) Drawer, bring a whole Bottle, I say, a whole Bottle. Look you, d'you see, I will begin my Ladies health in a whole Bottle, an it were as deep as a— Churm. And as I'm an honest man, I'll see my self pledg'd— Mr. Clark, here's to ye, with all my heart—

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Ah, pure Country-frolick▪

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: The Rogue's mad.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: How he stares—

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: And blows—

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: And sweats at it.—

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: How now, Mr. Trupenny?

sp.speaker: Trup.
sp.p: (down) Gentlemen, I drink fair.— This damn'd Rogue Drawer has gi'n me a Chair that wants a— wants a— one leg—

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Rather, you want two— Come, Clark, here's no more to be done. Now, which way are you bound?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Here, Drawer, here's the Reckoning— Faith, Iack, now I have recruited my Pockets indifferently well; I must directly into Holborn: I have a certain Intrigue there, with a Cutler's Wife, that must not be neglected. Farewel.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Drawer, run and fetch a Porter with a great Basket; and dost hear— [whispers]— you understand me?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: A little below Fetter-lane, say you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Yes. I leave this to thy manage: Do it ingeniously, and here's shilling for thy pains.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Thank ye, noble Master. Let me alone for Roguery— [to Trupenny]— Sir, Sir, will ye please to rise, and walk into the next Room? there's Company a coming hither that have bespoke a Dinner.

sp.speaker: Trup.
sp.p: E'faith, now, 'tis all off— and— e— gad I can drink no more.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Let me help ye up, Sir,— methinks you're something heavy— [searches his Pockets]— what a Devil, nothing but a few greasie Papers?—

sp.speaker: Trup.
sp.p: Nay, nay, nay— take off your Bottle, Mr. Spruce; Uds bud, I'll not bate ye an Ace, look ye.— Ho'now, what are you? the Drawer? Ah, poor little Drawer, let me kiss thee— where is Mr. Spruce, ye Rogue Drawer?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Sir, the Gentlemen are stept into the next Room, only to—

sp.speaker: Trup.
sp.p: As I hope to live, I'll follow them, and see my self pledged, and then,— call a Coach, ye Rogue— for I can drink no more, ye Rogue— but will go home like a Prince, ye Son of a Nine-eyes.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: This way, Sir.

div.stage: Enter Loveal sola, and after a while enter to her, Spruce.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Lord! what a wide Town is this London; I have been, I believe, in Forty several places, but cannot finde my Mistriss out— nor in all my Jaunt I have not met with Trupenny: Pray Heaven he be not spirited away by that strange French creature— Well, I dare swear she had the foul Disease, she spoke so strangely; for I have heard folk say, it alters the speech much: Out upon her for a filthy beast; I warrant it is so.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Mrs. Loveal! most happily met—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Mr. Spruce! I profess, I am glad I have met with some-body I know; I had like to have been spirited away, which so scared me, that I was forced to run for it; if I had not, I vow, I do believe I should ne're have seen Darbyshire more. But pray, Mr. Spruce, may I be so bold to ask where people use to be married in London? for my Mistris is gone with Mr. Docket on that designe, but I cannot find 'em—

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: If you will permit me the honour of waiting on you, I will show you the place—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir, I would not trouble you; but if you can tell me where our Steward Trupenny is, he shall go with me— I protest to you, he has not seen home since he went this morning to your Master's Chamber: I wonder where a murrain he should be!—

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: I left him just now drinking a Glass at the Cock-ale-house, with a Country-man of his, whom he met with by chance—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p:
The Devil take him; he'll get drunk, and then there will
be no ho with him: He is as mad as a Buck in Rutting-time, when he is in his Beer, as they say—

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: But, Mrs. Loveal, I have a Request to you, in behalf of a poor despairing Lover: good Soul, loosing his heart in your company, he is wandring about the Town to finde you out— for they are your Eyes have conquered him—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Nay, good Mr. Spruce, no more, if you love me; you act the flattering Courtier now— but I confess, I have had some languishing looks in my time; I will assure you, they have been called the Sun, Moon, and seven Stars too: Nay, I believe I can look killingly still; see, Mr. Spruce, do I not?—

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Such looks wou'd kill a Basilisk—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Nay, nay, I cou'd have done, but alas, alas, I grow old, yet not so old, but I have seen my Elders doated on, aye, and by young men too— I vow by my Virginity, I am but forty odd—

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: (aside) Virginity quoth a?— Aye marry, that is an age fit for a Lady Mayoress: women, especially Maids about Forty, are in their prime, being past the wanton years; but so fond and vain are young Virgins at thirty, that I have seen 'um hang about mens necks and kiss 'um, and doat on all they met.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Ha, ha, he, that is true; Trupenny knows it of me; but (though with much ado, I must tell you) I am honest, I can assure you— but not to appear uncivil, May I, without offence, desire to know who this poor creature is? for I pitty him heartily; and I vow to you, I am so charitable, I wou'd not have him cast himself away for me, poor Soul, for the world—

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: To say true, it is Dashwel, my fellow-clerk—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Loving Mr. Dashwel— now, Mr. Spruce, I dare swear Marriages are made in Heaven; for I must confess— yet, ha, ha, he, you will perhaps wonder at my confidence, I have had a great kindness for him from the first time I saw him— but I vow, I mean honestly—

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: But you have not only vanquished him, but another too that has seen you, is become your Admirer; and he being jealous of Dashwel, has on purpose sent him out of the way, that he might have the freer converse with you— and now—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Mr. Spruce, speak not for him— if you do, I must deny you; for I vow to you, I can like none but Mr. Dashwel—

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Then woe to unfortunate Spruce, that must die with despair— the wretchedest creature on the earth—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Lord, Mr. Spruce, is't you? hold, hold, Sir, and take some of my Spirit to comfort you— but I fear you do but play the rogue.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: I swear—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Nay, nay, I vow I believe you do not— and tell you true, you are the only man I wisht to be my Husband; and to show my good nature— see, I am ready to sacrifice my self to your will: But ha! bless me, what's here?

div.stage: Enter Porter with Trupenny in a basket: boys following.

sp.speaker: Trup.
sp.p: Why, you young Sons of Whores, what ado is here? did you ne're see a man ride in a Coach before?— Ha, Mr. Spruce, and my old Mother Midnight Loveal— So ho, Mr. Spruce. Mrs. Loveal, will you ride? hold Coach-man, hold you Rogue— Yfeck 'tis fine riding.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Now, out upon him for a beast, and a shame take all ill-luck, say I, for making me loose your good company: Now must I go put him to bed, or my Mistriss will lead me such a life— for he is my charge when he is in this condition— a filthie beast— farewel, sweet Mr. Spruce, till an hour hence, and then I will steal out to finish the business you wot of, if you think fit.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.l: Whose serious Passion merits more success:
This is but Love-burlesque, or something less.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter Truman, Ned Goodfeild, and Lucia.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: YOu see, Mr. Truman, I have performed what you desired; but know, had I not been well assured that that was true you told me, I should not have so soon, or easily consented: and I hope, Sir, you will not impute it either to folly or fondness, but to an Uncle's rigour, that made me act what now I have done.

sp.speaker: N. Good.
sp.p:
Far be it from me, Madam, to harbour such base thoughts
of one so Virtuous— but I shall ever acknowledge the favour my best of Friends hath done me.— And Friend, suspect not my Sisters fidelitie, for I know she has so just a sence of Honour, that what she promises she will perform: Yet, I must confess, her long stay somewhat startles me.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Use no farther motives, for they will rather induce me to cherish, than dissipate my breeding Jealousies: Her Country-innocence is an argument more prevailing than all your Rhetorick. Were she indeed one of the gay Ladies of the Town, whose words and actions ne're agree, I should have known how to have managed my Amour.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Your Boy, Mr. Truman, perhaps brings some news of the Lady—

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Sirrah, have you met with Madam Goodfeild?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Yes, Sir; and she is just now going to be married to a Gentleman that is with her.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: How, to another? Now, Ned, I begin to suspect thy fidelity.

sp.speaker: N. Good.
sp.p: It is impossible she should be false: the boy mistakes.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I am sure, Sir, that what I say is truth; for I sifted it out of their boy; who told me, his Lady Mrs. Goodfeild and Mr. Docket were going to be married.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Docket! bless'd mistake! it is thy Mother, Ned— now my hopes revive again.

sp.speaker: N. Good.
sp.p: Did not I tell thee, Iack, it was a mistake? but, Sirrah, are they not married yet?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: No, Sir, for one Parson denied them, the Canonical hour being past, and they having no License neither, so that now they are coming to Lincolns-Inn, in hopes to finde the Reader within, who is Mr. Docket's friend.

sp.speaker: N. Good.
sp.p: Better than I could have wisht. Iack, as thou lovest me or my Sister, contrive some way to hinder this match; I hate the thoughts of being controled or allied to such an impertinent Ignoramus— besides, who knows but he may wheedle her out of what would be our due, when she dies?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: They come; therefore retire, Ned, with thy Mistriss, and something I will do to manifest my Love for thy Sister— I have it—

sp.speaker: N. Good.
sp.p: Good luck attend thee.

div.stage: Enter Docket, Widow, Goodfeild, and Boy.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Oh, Mr. Docket, I am glad I have met you—

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: To see me married, you would say,— Why, look you, Mr. Truman, you must excuse me, that I did not invite you. Widows use to go to't with secresie; and for my part, I love not to blazon to the world what I am going about.

sp.speaker: W. Good.
sp.p: Pray, Mr. Docket, what Gentleman is that? he seems to be a person of Worth—

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: Why, lovely Bride, it is a worthy friend of mine, a man of a fair State, and sober Conversation— therefore for my sake salute him.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Madam, your humble Servant— but, Mr. Docket— your Niece—

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: My Niece? what of her?— Oh you like her— and would, with my consent, marrie her, and by that means relieve your Mortgage— Why look you, Mr. Truman, I want money— and you know—

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Right, I do know, Mr. Docket, that unless you make haste, your Niece will be stole away and married.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: How, stole away, and married? undone— undone— but now I think on it, let um if they dare, I'll bring my Writ of Ravishment de Gard against them: But for fear of the worst, good Friend, keep my Widow company till I step home, and I'll return immediately— Oh Heavens, my Niece stole! I'll firk un e'faith.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Now, Widow, since the old Goat is shifted off, let us make the best use of our time we can—

sp.speaker: W. Good.
sp.p: As how? I pray— (I hope he won't be uncivil—

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Why in chousing the old fool, by taking me into his place—

sp.speaker: W. Good.
sp.p: What, marrie you? that would be fine—

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Certain, Widow, there is some difference between me and the Lawyer Docket: First, I am younger, and consequently fitter for a Widow's service: In the next place, I am richer, to please her A varice: and lastly, not to flatter my self, I think I am handsomer to beget Christian-like Children; for, Agad, if this fellow get any, it must be with his Inkhorn, and what they will prove, judge you—

sp.speaker: W. Good.
sp.p: I vow, Sir, you are a pleasant Gentleman— but—

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: No buts, good Widow, but along, for I am all-over in Love; and till I overwhelm thee with kindness, I shall not be my self—

sp.speaker: W. Good.
sp.p: But may I trust to you, that you are inearnest?— I swear, a comely person, and so like Squire Goodfeild, that was! I warrant an able person— [aside] But, Sir, pray put none of your London▪ tricks on me: I fear you do but exercise your Wit upon me; for you Town-Gallants love to flout poor Countrie-Gentlewomen to make you sport—

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: If thou delayest one minute longer, Widow, I'll vow to blast thy Reputation, kill all that dare pretend to you, and at last, in spight of thy self, enjoy thee, and then Jilt thee—

sp.speaker: W. Good.
sp.p: Goodness! what prittie words you Gentlemen have; Jilt me? well, that must be some fine thing, it sounds so well; Jilt— I might have lived in Darbyshire to Methusabem's age, and not have heard such fine things.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Uds precious, Widow, what mean you?— swear instantly to be mine, or I vow, I will prosecute what I told you—

sp.speaker: W. Good.
sp.p: Hold, hold, Sir, I will swear or do any thing— but is this the London-way of Courtship?— It is somewhat boisterous, methinks, to force a woman to have a man whether she will or no— but Lord, what will Mr. Docket say, if I should cousin him?— I vow, now I think on't, I cannot, for my honour is engaged, and he has my word to be none but his—

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: What an unmannerly old-fashion'd Widow art thou to talk thus (in London too) of thy honour & word— when the most Heroick act an A-la-mode Lady can do, is to break promise, shake hands with Honour, and banish Reputation from her Dwelling.— Honour quoth a? Well, this is the last time of asking; and if denied, expect to see thy name in to morrow's Gazet, as an Advertisement to all young Gentlemen to beware of keeping thee companie, for fear of being infected with ten thousand Diseases more than e're were named in a Mountebanks Bill.

sp.speaker: W. Good.
sp.p: No more, good Sir, and here is my hand, I will be none but yours— but what shall we do about Mr. Docket? I would be loath, now he is set agog, as they say; he should be disappointed: were it my own case, I should not be pleased—

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Hang him— but however, I will contrive some means how to bestow him, now he is agog, as you say—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p:
So, I have put Trupenny to sleep, and now I will steal to
Mr. Spruce, who longs for my coming: I dare say, poor Soul— well, he is as loving good conditioned sweet natured young man as lives, though I say it.— Ha! my Lady here? if she sees me, I am ruined—

sp.speaker: W. Good.
sp.p: Oh, Loveal! were they my Son and Daughter we met an hour ago?—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: No, Madam, we were both mistaken; they were your beyond-Sea French folk, Papists I warrant they were, they had such hard names; and they jabber'd so, it would have frightned you to have heard them speak.

sp.speaker: W. Good.
sp.p: I durst to have sworn it had been them—

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Is this your Maid, Madam?—

sp.speaker: W. Good.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, for want of a better—

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Fortune is kinder to us than we could have expected— What should hinder your Maid supplying your place, and marrie Mr. Docket?

sp.speaker: W. Good.
sp.p: Why nothing, Sir, sure; for now I shall oblige her, and keep my word too; for she to sadly longs for a Husband, that I was forced to promise to help her to one; and I must have bought one, rather than have failed, or I should have led a tedious life with her—

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Well, Madam, if you will give her a little instructions how to personate your self, I will step to the Temple in the interim, and finde out a Parson there to compleat our business, and in the Cloysters I will expect you— till then, dear Widow, your Servant. In the mean time let my Boy attend you.

sp.speaker: W. Good.
sp.p: Your humble Servant, Sir— Loveal, I remembring my promise to you, have accordingly found out a Husband for you. This Gentleman that is gone—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Well, this London is a brave place for Husbands; I wonder not now what makes the Countrie-maids flock up so fast to it— had I known so much before, I wou'd not have stayed so long in Darbyshire— and I vow, this Gentleman is as handsome a man as ever a Darbyshire-blade of 'um all.

sp.speaker: W. Good.
sp.p: Hold, you are too fast, Loveal, this is not the man, but he and I have found out one for you.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: How, is not he the man? nay, then, Madam, know, I have not been so long in Town, but that my good fortune has provided for me; and had not your Ladyship seen me, within an hour I had altered my condition.

sp.speaker: W. Good.
sp.p: What, were you going to be married? to whom I pray?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Either to Mr. Dashwel, or Mr. Spruce, I know not which; for both, poor things, are so much in love with me, that I was resolved to marry the first of 'um I met.

sp.speaker: W. Good.
sp.p: Dashwel and Spruce? Come, come, you are a fool; but be rul'd by me, and you shall marry their Master.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Mr. Docket! now, Madam, you jeer me; for I cannot believe you will give him away from your self.

sp.speaker: W. Good.
sp.p: Thou may'st be sure, Wench, I have provided otherwaies for my self, or I should hardly have parted with him.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Well, Madam, do with me as you please: for since I have had Love made to me, my minde so runs on Matrimony, that I shall not be my self till I have enter'd into that delicious kinde of life.

sp.speaker: W. Good.
sp.p: See, Mr. Docket comes; here, put on my great Scarf and Vail, and be sure not to show your face till you come home, but pretend an unusual Modesty, and play no old Ape's tricks of Fondness, but behave your self decently, and counterfeit my Speech, for he must take you for me; and when he comes, ask him if he has found his Niece.— Do you think you can do all this? I much doubt your Ability.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I'll warrant you, Madam— what not remember how to wheedle a man, and of this Age? it has been my practice this twenty years: But I must confess, my over-forwardness was the cause of my ill success; but I'll have more wit hereafter; and if I carry it not swimmingly, may I die before I taste the sweets of Matrimony, which is a most insupportable Curse.

sp.speaker: W. Good.
sp.p: Be sure you take heed; my Honour will suffer if you prove too coming, as they phrase it.— And now for my smug handsome young Gentleman.— Well, Mr. Docket, you may thank your self for this deceit; for by your own confession he is richer, and my own eyes tell me he is both handsomer and younger, and consequently fitter to satisfie a Widows love.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: Certainly there is more in it than I can apprehend, that Mr. Truman should tell me such a storie! for I met Dashwel, and he protestando said, my Niece was safe at home. Ha! well thought on, if he should be stolen away with my Widow?— How, how, no Truman! Docket, Docket, where's thy Widow, man?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: [counterfeiting W. Good.] Oh, Mr. Docket, that unmannerly clownish friend of yours left me alone so soon as you was gone; but I was resolved to stay, were it till midnight: But pray now, have you found your Niece?

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: It is her voice— Sing O be joyful— Widow mine, my Niece is safe— and now I have thee once more, I am resolved not to let thee go till we have joyned Issue— But why this Vail? A Widow and bashful? for shame turn up— in troth I will bring a Levari facias.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Hold, hold, Mr. Docket, let me hide my blushes; when we are fast to one another, as they say, then you shall turn up what you please.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: Say'st thou so, Widow? along, along then, for fear of another Demurrer.

div.head: SCENE II.
