div.stage: Enter Dashwel hastily: After him, B. Goodfeild, and Frank, in Vizards.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: WHat would she have? I know her not. Has she not pickt my pocket?

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: This is the rarest Mortal I ever met with: see how the Rogue shakes! But Mr. Anthony—

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: I say once more, Gentlewoman, you are mistaken; my name is neither Iohn, Humphery, Dick, Rowland, Ieossery, Stephen, Anthony, nor Mark Anthony neither, but plain Thomas Dashwel, senior Clerk to Mr. Docket.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Your Father-in-law's Clerk, on my life, Madam. A word, Sir; is not your Master an Attourney of Cliffords-Inn?

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Yes, and Gentleman too.

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: He is about marrying a Darbyshire-widow—

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Yes, yes, they are Legitimo Matrimonio copulat ' by this time.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Her name, Goodfeild—

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Right— If this should be the Devil I have been talking with all this while?

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: Friend, haste to thy Master, tell him if he marries the Widow, this night will prove his last: I have decreed it, I his fate have said it.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: It is a Devil, o'my conscience; would I were rid of her company. Nay, nay, nay, pray forsooth keep more distance— Look, look, her Eyes are all of a flame, and I shall be damn'd before my time!

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: What a Rogue am I to disappoint a longing Widow? but when she shall know it was for younger flesh, she will not certainly be so unreasonable to blame me.— Well, her Daughter is a witty wilde frollicking Raskal, and I love her to excess; but her absence sets my patience on the Rack.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Oh, Mr. Truman, I am glad you are come.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: What's the matter, man? thou look'st as if thou wert scared out of thy little Wits.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Wits quoth I? here stands, I fear, the Ruines of one who once was a hopeful Pleader. See, see, Mr. Truman, this Petticoat-Sathan has made divers and sundry assaults manus graviter imposuit, & cetera, insultum fecit vi & armis verbis opprobriis & minis— I have a good minde to swear the Peace against her— But oh, good sweet Mr. Truman— she approaches; as I hope to draw a Plea again, I will be gone, and so the Devil take the hindmost.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Some well-meaning Punck, on my life, following her Calling. It is easier to see a Court-Lady in her natural Complexion, than Fleet-street and the Temples without this kinde of Cattle.

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: Have at my Temple-lover once more; if he proves according to my wish, he is my own. I'll trie if he is one of the Fashionable Town-Gallants, who, good-natur'd Souls, keep Wenches for others as well as for themselves.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: If he proves constant after all these tryals, with my consent he should be Chronicled.

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: Your name is Truman, as I take it.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: You take it right.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: And for want of wit, your dull sottish Worship is entering into the bonds of Matrimonie.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: How the Devil came you to know it? 'tis neither in Gazet, nor Banes yet askti'th ' Church.

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: Gad sa' me, y'are a base perfidious fellow.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Dam me! a Raskal.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Hie day, Petticoat-hectors?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: To use a Lady thus?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Use her? how? what Lady? which of ye?

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: Me, ungrateful man? but I'll have your throat cut, Mister—

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Or nose slit, look ye.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Dashwel's words prove true; these are a couple of Devils: Nothing but Bloud and Wounds! 'Sbud who are ye? and why this anger to me, Damsels?

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: Treacherous perjur'd Villain, who was not only content to debauch me, a poor innocent Country-girl— but notwithstanding thousands of protestations of keeping me with a gilt Coach, and set of Horses for three lives, or one and twenty years, at last to Jilt me. But hang you, Renegado, your promises, performances, and treats, prove all too sligh tfor a Ladies service.— Follow me, if you dare.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Villain? perjur'd? debaucht? gilt Coach? Jilt me? treats? What a Pox is the meaning of all this? Hold, hold, Madam Mystery, Gad e're you and I part, you must explain your self a little better.

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: Unworthy man, how often did you treat me at Plays, the Park, and Mulberry-garden, before I yielded? Have you forgot that too— and how you carried me to Tunbridge?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Yes, Madam; by the same token he had not money enough to pay the lodging, so that you were forced to pledge your little Dog for Nine and six pence, to save his honour— 'Tis true, when we came to London he sent his Taylor to redeem him, which he put to his account for this Suit he has on; but I suppose you do not remember this?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Thou— I know not what! a Puppie save my Honour? thou riddleing lying Sathan, vanish, or—

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I warrant you have forgot too, how last Winter you presented me a Gennet Muff of a Noble, and at the same time promised me a Ring worth five Guinies, on condition I would praise your Dancing to my Lady: which I did, but from that hour to this, I never saw or Ring or Gold.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Oh, impudent Jilt!

sp.speaker: B. Good,
sp.p: Faithless man! consider who it is that courts you to be constant.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Think of her Beauty and Behaviour.

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: Her Faith in violate.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Her singular Modesty!

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Aye, her Modesty; but above all, her Bloud and Affinity: Think of her Relations at Court, able to promote you to what Pitch she pleases: Half a word from her, can make you a Justice of Quorum, and send you into the Country with a Commission to domineer over your Betters. I'll tell you as a secret, there is my Lord— hum— and Sir Thomus— hum— have been her Couzins any time this six years, off and on.

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: In fine, tell me, as you are a Gentleman and no Souldier, how can you finde in your heart to forsake a Lady thus, and undo your self by marrying?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: To forsake one that loves you, to be tied to one for life, who without question, if she has any wit, as you are Husband, will hate and Cuckold you— Ha, ha, he.

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: Aye, one that loves and doats upon you— Ha, ha, he.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Was ever man thus baited by a couple of Vizard-masks?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Faith I think not.

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: Oh that I were but a man, for thy sake! I have been too much a woman, I'm sure.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Nay, nay, Madam, rather than fail, I'll hire a pair of Breeches at the next Broakers, and then break his pate, for all this.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Why, thou, thou, what shall I call thee? thou unheard-of Jilt, and thou other Spirit of impudence, what Devil set you on to abuse me thus? Follow me no further, but tremble at the Neighbourhood of Bridewel, and be silent.

sp.speaker: N. Good.
sp.p: How now, Sister! what do you here?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: How? his Sister! 'Slife I am ruined.

sp.speaker: N. Good.
sp.p: Oh, Iack here too!— then I perceive the business is done betwixt my Sister and you.— Methinks you walk at distance like man and wife already.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: No, Ned, it is undone, and I so too, if you stand not my friend to her: thy Sister, whom I had never seen in her own Habit before, has provoked me to do that I fear will blast that good opinion she before had entertained of me.

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: Fear not, Sir, I like you never the worse for what has past, especially considering who was the cause of your passion, and of whom the discourse was supposed to be. Like a wise Physitian who has made a Patient sick by trying Experiments, I now will apply that remedy which will, I suppose, reduce you to your Wits agen. Here— how say you?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Gad, now I have you, Madam, hang me if I quit my hold till we are made Yoak-fellows: and if I trust you more out of my sight—

sp.speaker: N. Good.
sp.p: So; away, and I will follow presently.

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: Do you know what a dreadful thing it is you go about?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Think not to scare me, Madam; for so long as every couple hitherto, both good and bad, have had at least a month of pleasure, I am resolved to trie what it is. Madam, it is decreed, and so forth— Dear Rogue, let us to it.—

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: Enter on one side, Docket, Loveal: On the other, Ned Goodfeild, Lucia.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: HOw, how's this? my Niece with a stranger? undone, undone. Now I begin to suspect Dashwel is false, and all was true which Mr. Truman told me.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: My Uncle, Sir! what shall I do?

sp.speaker: N. Good.
sp.p: Fear. nothing, Madam, I will be your shield against his anger.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: Niece, Niece, Niece, Baggage, a word I pray— What Gentleman is that? what, what have ye been doing together? why don't you answer me? what is he? from whence? whither wou'd he? with whom wou'd he speak?— ha—

sp.speaker: N. Good.
sp.p: Why, faith Sir, I am a Cantabrigian, a Gentleman, and my business was with this Lady; and we have dispatched the very same Affair as you and my Mother have been about, To have and to hold, for better for worse, and so forth; and now in hopes you will pardon a wandring Son, Madam, I beg a blessing on this Lady and my self.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: How? married, married! Cuds lid married?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p:
Now I am sure this is my young Master Edward; and because
he takes me for my Lady, for once I will act the part of a Mother [aside.] Son Edward, you have it; but how came it to pass you left Cambridge? who gave you leave, pray, to come up to this lewd Town? go to, it is not well done of you.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: Widow that was, is this your Son?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Yes, Mr. Docket, and a witty childe he is, but much of his Father's resolute humour, Peace be with him: for if at any time I desired him not to do so, or so, be sure he would do't; therefore I cannot blame him. But Son, are you married to that Gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: N. Good.
sp.p: As sure as you are to Mr. Docket, Madam.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: But not with my consent. However, Sir, for your Mothers sake, who is now my bride, this likewise being our Wedding-day, I pardon you: But d'you hear? expect nothing from me.

sp.speaker: N. Good.
sp.p: Lass, Sir, I should be too unreasonable to expect anything from you besides the Portion her Father left her; Six thousand pounds will satisfie me well enough.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: But let me tell you, Sir, she has not Six thousand groats, marrying without my consent, as by her Father's Will may and doth more fully appear.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: — Now I have it— Then, Sir, I hope you will not desire or expect to intermeddle with my Concerns: I have but Six hundred pounds a year Joynture, besides Four or Five thousand pounds in Money, Plate, and Goods; but these are not worth speaking of.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: How, so wealthy? nay, then I am friends— It is but three or four years forbearance, and I shall cheat her of as much as the Portion comes to; therefore 'twill be policie to comply [Aside]— Well, Sir, for your Mothers sake I am reconciled to you, and must confess—

div.p: Six thousand pounds is my Nieces Portion, which in truth I cannot keep from her, it being by the Will due upon her day of marriage; and my designe in giving out the Penalty, was in hopes that no one wou'd have ventured on her; and she dying single, her Portion then would have been my own.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: To which we are Witnesses.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: Oh, Mr. Truman! with all my heart.

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: Brother, give you joy— Mother, your Blessing

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I can hold no longer— [discovers her self] Oh, Mrs. Betty, I am over-joyed to see you in London—

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: How, how's this? what cheated of my Widow too? Wretched miserable Docket, thou art undone, undone—

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Fear not that, man; she's a thrifty Soul I warrant you. But Docket, cou'dst thou in thy Conscience think it reasonable to swallow Widows as fast as Mortgages? No, Sir, no; and you see now, that by my own contrivance, without the help of the Chancery, I have superseded your desires: ha, ha, he—

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: Look ye, I will instantly draw up an Indictment against ye all for Cheats.

sp.speaker: N. Good.
sp.p: And I will immediately take out a Writ against you for my wifes Portion; you understand me?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: But provided you give an Appearance, and put in good Bayl, you shall not be arrested; for you know Six thousand pounds requires special Bayl, Mr. Docket. But to prevent such extremity, I will make a bold proposal.— Deliver up my Mortgage, and I will become responsible to my friend for your Nieces Portion.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: Hum! Deliver up your Mortgage, Sir? Curia advisare unit: let me consider on it.

sp.speaker: N. Good.
sp.p: Do it, and I agree to't with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: [aside] Here is no parting with Money, for it is the same sum; and should I be stubborn, they'll have me up in Chancery, and that will soak my Purse.— And I have now what I have long'd for many a day; a Wife, though none of the best, yet she'll serve.— Mr. Truman, I'll do't; and let all bear witness, I here promise to deliver up Mr. Truman's Mortgage, provided that upon receipt thereof he enters into Bond to my Nephew and Niece for the payment of her Portion. In the mean time, Nephew, I give it you— And now, Sir, I give you Joy with all my heart.

sp.speaker: N. Good.
sp.p: Your Servant, Sir.— And now, friend, before these, I give you back your Mortgage in lieu of my Sisters Portion.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: Well done, y'faith, Nephew— how luckily it falls out! Two Portions paid, and a Mortgage satisfied, without handling one farthing of Money.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Advance, man, and see thy Mistriss in earnest, for she is my Master's Wife now.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Married to my Master? I will instantly have him up in the Ecclesiastical Court de Matrimonio preloquut ', for that will amount to a Contract.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Spare thy pains, man, he'll be too hard for thee at that weapon; and since he has her, we must submit to our hard fortune.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Well, patience per force, et cetera— but what a Raskal was you to make me run the Gauntlet about the Town?

sp.speaker: W. Good.
sp.p: Hist, hist, Mr. Truman, Mr. Truman—

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: Your Blessing, Madam.

sp.speaker: W. Good.
sp.p: My Pardon you mean, for making me wait so long.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: this Lady, Madam, was pleased to forbid the Banes, and take me her self.

sp.speaker: W. Good.
sp.p: How's this? my Daughter? Lord, Betty, what make you in London?

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: Madam, understanding your desire of having me married, I thought London the likeliest place to meet with a good Husband in, which since I have found true; and I thank my Stars I am better matcht than I shou'd ha'been with Sir Alexander—

sp.speaker: W. Good.
sp.p: My Son Edward in Town too?

sp.speaker: N. Good.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, and begs both Pardon and blessing; for Mr. Docket's Niece and I have been at the same sport my Sister and Friend have been at.

sp.speaker: W. Good.
sp.p: What a day of Accidents has this been! my Journey made fruitless, my Children married, and my self disappointed— But Mr. Truman.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: I understand you, Madam— but enough of that— cou'd you in reason, expect to have two Husbands before your Daughter had one?

sp.speaker: W. Good.
sp.p: This vexes me a little: however, I'll carry it off 〈◊〉 moothly [aside.] I swear, Mr. Truman, you have had singular good fortune, to meet with a Wife; for cou'd you think I was in 〈◊〉 arnest? that so Grave and Sober a person as my self wou'd marry 〈◊〉 o light a young London gallant as you are? I thought only to 〈◊〉 ave made sport with you, and to let you know that Country- Gentlewomen can carry on designes, and have wit upon occasion, 〈◊〉 s well as your fine flanting Londoners, an they list.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: That I suspected; besides, Madam, I had not the ambition on to be your Husband; your Son, was the greatest happiness I aim'd at— which, by my Friends assistance, and this Ladies kinde consent, I am according to my wish.

sp.speaker: W. Good.
sp.p: I cannot be angry with you; for your marrying my Daughter, shows you have a Respect for me— therefore Heaven bless you together; and here I publickly promise not to marry again— but be good Children, and when I die, share what I leave behinde me.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: We are obliged to you.

sp.speaker: B. Good.
sp.p: Frank, suspect me not; thy service shall be rewarded: I hate Ingratitude.— Finde out the man you can like for a Husband, and I promise thee a Portion, Wench.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: With your pardon, Madam— I am of too modish a nature, to comply with so ungentile a thing as Matrimony: my Request is only this, that you'll be pleas'd to accept of my service, while I am serviceable; but when I grow old and past my labour, as they say, a small allowance for Pap, Butter-milk, and roasted Chesnuts is all I desire.

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: In the mean time, know me for your Gallant; for when that dreadful Winter of Age comes, you'll be good for nothing but to make Touchwood.

sp.speaker: N. Good.
sp.p: Mr. Spruce, your Service has been so considerable, that when opportunity offers, I never will appear ungrateful.—

sp.speaker: Spr.
sp.p: Your Servant, Sir.

sp.speaker: Dock.
sp.p: So, so, all's concluded, and I am very well satisfied with my Spouse here, seeing the Widow has mist of her Aim— and being my Wedding-night, my Niece disposed of too— Dashwel, come hither; run you before to the Rose-Tavern, and bid 'um send the Supper I bespoke to Cliffords-Inn-Hall; and then step to the Cock-ale-house and get Fiddles, for I am resolv'd, Gallants, to dance the Measures e're I go to bed— and then—

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Aye, marry Sir; shall I see Argulius, and O basse Regis danced agen? I love those Temple-dances with all my heart.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Agreed, agreed.—

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.p: This Generous Frolick of thine, old Lawyer, has quite reconcil'd me to thee; and I am resolv'd to make Quarrels, but I'll be thy Client for this— Lead thy way with thy Duck there—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Aye, aye, let's be going, I begin to grow very sleepy, my Dear.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.l: Gray heads may doat, as their dull Passions move;
But only Heaven and Youth make perfect Love.

div.head: ERRATA.
div.p: PAge 25. line 31. read le Peak. p. 47. l. 8. r. erre. p. 53. l. 7. r. with whom I left him. p. 70. l. 30. r. certainly.

div.head: EPILOGUE.
div.l: THe plague of Writing has infected all;
'Tis a Disease grown epidemical,
And not confin'd to th' bounds of this lewd Town,
But o're the Nation the Infection's slown.
For Country-Squires now drunken Catches write,
Whilst Miss is here lampoon'd by Iilted Knight.
The brisk gay Fop, and modest Lover too,
With senseless Rimes coy Mistrisses persue.
Nay, the great man, Heir to more Wealth than Wit,
From Authors steals, yet swears those lines he writ:
But he (suspecting you the cheat shou'd finde)
Both to himself, and world, will prove so kinde
To let you know in Verse a piece of's minde.
Then blundring through the streams of Poetric
He knowingly displays Debaucherie,
Which proves to be his own Epitomie.
The Zealot too, (as I'm inform'd) through th' Nose
Pronounc'd a fatal Sentence against Prose:
For being inspir'd with Brother Hopkins Rime,
He wooes a Sister in the like jangling Chime.
Nay, shou'd w'enquire, no doubt there are but few
Amongst ye here, but what are Dablers too;
And Muse as well as Miss for kindness sue.
It is the worlds blinde side— then, Sirs, forbear
Your censures now, lest fondly ye appear,
Not to our Author, but t'your selves severe.
Though plain, 'tis new, your Rigour then suspend,
Since to divert you this he did intend.
If all should write alike, then where wou'd be
Your blest Diana, sweet Varietie?
